word.name: abtruse
word.meaning: hard to understand
word.example: e.g. When we can recall events from our dreams, they seem abtruse to us
word.etymology: from the Latin abstrudere: to conceal

word.name: actuate
word.meaning: to put into motion
word.example: e.g. When you leave the house, you must tap in a pin code to actuate the alarm
word.etymology: from the medieval Latin actuare: to carry out

word.name: acuity
word.meaning: sharpness of mind or of the senses
word.example: e.g. The oratory of Barack Obama's speeches reflects his intellectual acuity
word.etymology: from the Latin acuere: to sharpen

word.name: adage/aphorism
word.meaning: a proverb expressing a universal truth
word.example: e.g. One of Oscar Wilde's best-known aphorisms/adages is: 'a little sincerity is a dangerous thing, and a great deal of it is absolutely fatal'
word.etymology: adage derives from the Latin adagium: a saying (based on an early form of aio: I say); aphorism from the Greek aphorismos: a definition

word.name: adduce
word.meaning: to cite by way of evidence
word.example: e.g. Mark Twain passed on investing in Alexander Bell's telephone, wrongly adducing that static on the line would mean no one would buy the device
word.etymology: from the Latin adducere, from ad: toward, and ducere: to lead

word.name: adjunct
word.meaning: a thing added to something else but not as a non-core part
word.example: e.g. Women find that more attention from men is an adjunct to breast augmentation
word.etymology: from the Latin ad: to, and jungere: to join

word.name: adjutant
word.meaning: a deputy
word.example: e.g. To show he was serious about his government being a coalition, Conservative David Cameron appointed Liberal Democrat Nick Clegg as his adjutant
word.etymology: from the Latin adjuvare: to assist

word.name: aegis
word.meaning: the protection of a particular body
word.example: e.g. George Bush Snr was forced to punish Saddam from attacking Kuwait because Kuwait is under the aegis of the US
word.etymology: According to The Iliad, the aegis (or aigis in Greek) was the shield wielded by Zeua, the king of gods. From the shield hung one hundred golden tassels, which were depicted by Classical vase-painters as writhing snakes. Today, we continue to use the word aegis to denote any protection afforded to one person by another and it is often used to describe one country's looking after another in the international arena.

word.name: agent provocateur
word.meaning: a person who seeks to harm another by provoking them to commit an unlawful or wrong act
word.example: e.g. In the film Donnie Brasco, Johnny Depp plays an FBI agent who infiltrates the Mafia and encourages their criminality; Depp is an agent provocateur
word.etymology: from the French agent provocateur: inciting agent

word.name: alabaster
word.meaning: smooth and white
word.example: e.g. Nicole Kidman's ginger locks contrast with her alabaster skin
word.etymology: from the Latin alabaster: a perfume casket made from the mineral alabaster; alabaster literally means 'resembling disaster, a white variety of gypsum'

word.name: aleatory
word.meaning: random
word.example: e.g. Travelling across London at the weekend can be a somewhat aleatory experience in view of the improvement works on the underground
word.etymology: from the Latin alea: a game of dice (singular of 'die'); aleatory literally means 'depending on the toss of a die'

word.name: amanuensis
word.meaning: an assistant to an artist
word.example: e.g. Agatha Christie had difficulty with writing and spelling owing to a learning disability so dictated all her detective stories to an amanuensis
word.etymology: from the Latin (servus) a manu: (slave) at hand (writing), and ensis: belonging to

word.name: amulet
word.meaning: a small piece of jewellery thought to ward off evil
word.example: e.g. After breaking up with his fiancée, James Dean wore an enamel locket containing strands of her hair: this was his lucky amulet
word.etymology: Examples of amulets include gems, rings and coins; all these objects are small enough to carry around and are believed to bring good luck to the bearer. Amulets also exist in larger form and perhaps the most famous amulet is the crucifix, which is found in the homes of Christians to protect against evil

word.name: anachronistic
word.meaning: very old-fashioned
word.example: e.g. The Tower of London is guarded by Beefeaters who dress anachronistically.
word.etymology: from the Greek anakhronismos, from ana: backward, and khronos: time; anachronistic literally means appropriate to a different time.

word.name: anaemic
word.meaning: lacking in vigour
word.example: e.g. Compared with Rita Hayworth and other voluptuous stars of the day, Grace Kelly appeared anaemic.
word.etymology: from the Greek anaemia, from an: without, and haima: blood; anaemic literally means 'suffering from anaemia'; this is a medical condition caused by a deficiency of red blood cells, resulting in paleness and weakness.

word.name: anodyne
word.meaning: not contentious, often deliberately so
word.example: e.g. The Great Gatsby author F. Scott Fitzgerald didn't believe in anodyne entrances, once turning up to a Hollywood party on all fours and barking.
word.etymology: from the Greek anodunos: painless, from an: without, and odune: pain

word.name: anomic
word.meaning: lacking normal ethical standards
word.example: e.g. Serial killer Fred West murdered people on a whim; he was an anomic individual.
word.etymology: from the Greek anomos: lawless

word.name: antediluvian
word.meaning: so old-fashioned as to be ridiculous
word.example: e.g. Critics of the Catholic Church view the refusal to ordain woman as antediluvian.
word.etymology: from the Latin ante: before, and diluvium: flood. antediluvian literally means 'from a time before the flood created by God to punish man'

word.name: anthropogenic
word.meaning: created by humans
word.example: e.g. The ozone is shrinking due to anthropogenic carbon dioxide emissions.
word.etymology: from the Greek anthropos: human being and genic: produced by.

word.name: anthropomorphise
word.meaning: to attribute human form to something not human, such as an animal
word.example: e.g. Humans like watching dogs open doors with their paws - as though they had hands - because we like to anthropomorphise animals.
word.etymology: from the Greek anthropos: human being, and morphe: form

word.name: apocryphal
word.meaning: of dubious authenticity, but relayed as if true (and having the ring of truth)
word.example: e.g. Although it is true that he declared himself Emperor, the story that Napoleon performed the coronation himself is apocryphal - this duty went to Pope Pius VII.
word.etymology: apocryphal from the Greek noun Apocrypha, which means 'having been hidden away'. The early Christian Church gave this label to religious writings considered useful but not inspired by God - hence these volumes were excluded from the accepted canon of scripture. Today, when we label a story apocryphal, it means we are casting doubt on its authenticity.

word.name: apologist
word.meaning: a person who defends a cause that people find controversial
word.example: e.g. Apologists for Nazism are treated with contempt by most people.
word.etymology: from the Greek apologizesthai: to give an account.

word.name: apostatise
word.meaning: to abandon a religious or political belief
word.example: e.g. In some interpretations of sharia law, Muslims who have apostatised deserve death.
word.etymology: from the Greek apostates: a runaway slave.

word.name: apparatchik
word.meaning: an official in a huge organisation
word.example: e.g. Within the Conservative Party, George Osborne is no mere apparatchik, for he is one of David Cameron's closest advisers and the Chancellor.
word.etymology: from the Russian, apparat: apparatus, and chik: denoting agent.

word.name: apposite
word.meaning: appropriate
word.example: e.g. It is apposite to wear black to a funeral.
word.etymology: from the Latin appositus, past participle of apponere: to apply (from ad: toward, and ponere: to put)

word.name: approbation
word.meaning: approval
word.example: e.g. Bill Gates' donates of billions to charity was greeted with global approbation.
word.etymology: from the Latin approbare: to approve.

word.name: Arcadian
word.meaning: relating to a paradise in the country
word.example: e.g. Many town-dwellers dream of leading Arcadian existence.
word.etymology: Arcadia is in Greek mythology the home of Pan, the god of flocks and herds; hence today the use of the word Arcadia to signify a rural paradise. (Incidentally, the god Pan gives us another word derived from his name: panic. This is because the Greeks represented Pan as being frightening in appearance - having the horns and legs of a goat but a man's body - which caused anyone who saw him to panic).

word.name: arcane
word.meaning: shut off to outsiders, hence mysterious
word.example: e.g. To a Christian, the customs of a Muslim wedding ceremony - such as the elaborate decorating of the bride's hands and feet with henna seems arcane.
word.etymology: from the Latin arca: a chest, from arcere: to shut up.

word.name: archipelago
word.meaning: islands grouped together; OR a sea containing islands grouped together
word.example: e.g. The West Indies form an archipelago lying between the Caribbean Sea and the Atlantic Ocean.
word.etymology: from the Greek arkhi: chief, and pelagos: sea

word.name: argot
word.meaning: the slang of a particular clique
word.example: e.g. The police are called 'the pigs' in the argot of criminals.
word.etymology: from the French argot: slang

word.name: arriviste
word.meaning: an ambitious person who has recently 'made it'
word.example: e.g. People who have inherited wealth regard people whose wealth derives from their own endeavours as arrivistes.
word.etymology: from the French arriver: to arrive

word.name: assiduous
word.meaning: very diligent
word.example: e.g. Conspiracy theorists say the disappearance of the phone records for Marilyn Monroe's flat on the night of her death is evidence of an assiduous cover-up.
word.etymology: from the Latin assidere: to be engaged in doing.

word.name: atavistic
word.meaning: concerning the re-emergence of traits that had disappeared generations ago
word.example: e.g. A human foetus starts life with a tail; but as the foetus grows this atavistic feature drops off.
word.etymology: from the Latin atavus: forefather.

word.name: attrition
word.meaning: the process to slowly reducing the strength of someone or something by pressure over time
word.example: e.g. By continually returning the ball, Rafael Nadal wears out his opponent by a process of attrition.
word.etymology: from the Latin atterere: to rub.

word.name: Augean
word.meaning: needing so much effort to finish as to seem impossible
word.example: e.g. After overthrowing Saddam Hussain, President Bush faced the Augean task of establishing a democracy in Iraq.
word.etymology: Augean derives from the name of King Augean, who was best known in Greek mythology for his stables, which held the biggest herd of cattle in the country. These cattle were so strong and healthy - in fact divinely so - that they produced huge heaps of dung every day, meaning that no one could ever clean out the stables properly. One of Hercule's 12 labours was to make these stables clean in just 24 hours; he succeeded in this by diverting the path of two rivers into the buildings, thus sweeping away the excrement. Today we continue to refer to any task that seems impossible as Augean.

word.name: (auspices) under the auspices of
word.meaning: with the protection of
word.example: e.g. When Russia invaded Georgia, the UN objected because Georgia falls under the auspices of the UN.
word.etymology: The expression under the auspices of derives from the Latin auspicium, which means an observation by a soothsayer who relied on the flight of birds to divine the future. Auspicium itself derives from the Latin words avis: a bird, and specere: to observe.

word.name: autocrat
word.meaning: someone who demands total obedience from other people
word.example: e.g. Idi Amin was an autocrat who ruled Uganda with an iron rod, tolerating no dissent.
word.etymology: from the Greek autokrates, from autos: self, and kratos: power; an autocrat literally means 'a ruler who has absolute power'.

word.name: autodidact
word.meaning: a self-taught person
word.example: e.g. He left school with no qualifications, became an autodidact and now lectures the world over Italian art.
word.etymology: from the Greek autodidaktos: self-taught, from autos: self, and didaktos: taught.

word.name: automaton
word.meaning: a person who seems to behave in a way that is more mechanical than human
word.example: e.g. Author Virgina Woolf drowned herself by putting stones into her pockets and walking calmly into a river like an automaton.
word.etymology: from the Greek automatos: acting of itself, from autos: self, and matos: willing.

word.name: bacchanalian
word.meaning: characterised by drunkenness and partying
word.example: e.g. After success in Hollywood, Marilyn Monroe developed an addiction to pills and Don Perignon; hers was a bacchanalian lifestyle.
word.etymology: bacchanalian originates from the name of Bacchus, a Roman god. Bacchus was at first the god of fertility in nature and was thus at the centre of wild religious ceremonies; later Bacchus continued this association with abandonment by being known as the god of wine who reduced inhibitions and promoted creativity in the arts. (Bacchus was the name given by the Romans to the Greek God Dionysus, see Dionysian)

word.name: badinage
word.meaning: witty talk
word.example: e.g. The Queen Mother used to enjoy a nightly gin and tonic along with some badinage.
word.etymology: from the French badiner: to joke.

word.name: bathetic
word.meaning: relating to an anticlimax
word.example: e.g. 'Does nobody understand?' were the final words of novelist James Joyce: a bathetic last statement for such a master of communication.
word.etymology: from the Greek bathos: depth

word.name: beetle-browed
word.meaning: (of a person's eyebrows) shaggy and projecting
word.example: e.g. Old men who do not trim their eyebrows become beetle-browed
word.etymology: from the Old English beetle, and brow, which meant 'eyebrow' (not 'forehead' as it does today).

word.name: behemoth
word.meaning: a huge thing, especially an enormous organisation
word.example: e.g. Jonathan Ross was one of the highest-paid employees of the behemoth that is the BBC.
word.etymology: from the Hebrew, behemoth: beast

word.name: bellicose
word.meaning: eager to fight
word.example: e.g. Ghengis Khan's bellicose nature led to conquests that created one of the largest empires in history.
word.etymology: from the Latin bellicus: pertaining to war.

word.name: benighted
word.meaning: ignorant due to a lack of education
word.example: e.g. The credit crunch began when onerous mortgages issued to financially benighted families in America went unpaid.
word.etymology: from the 16th century English benight: cover in darkness.

word.name: bifurcate
word.meaning: to split up into two branches
word.example: e.g. By day Dr Jekyll was a model citizen but at night he turned into the monstrous Mr Hyde: the man led a bifurcated life.
word.etymology: from the Latin bifurcus: two-forked, from bi: two, and furca: fork.

word.name: billous
word.meaning: full of spite
word.example: e.g. Rock Hudson's agent arranged for the star to marry his secretary so that the press would not direct billous comments towards Rock about his homosexuality.
word.etymology: billous derives from the Latin billis, meaning 'bile', which is a bitter fluid emitted by the liver to aid digestion; the ancient Greeks believed that bile had a negative influence on someone's mood (hence our use of the word billous today to signify a bad-tempered person). Note that the word billous has the following extra meanings: (of a person) feeling sick; (of a colour) so vivid as to be sickly

word.name: bilk
word.meaning: to take money (from someone) using deceitful methods
word.example: e.g. The young Errol Flynn was sacked from his jock as a clerk when he bilked money from petty cash to bet on a horse.
word.etymology: bilk is a variant of 'balk'; a mid 17th-century English word meaning 'to spoil one's opponent's score in the card game cribbage'

word.name: bipartisan
word.meaning: involving the agreement of two political parties usually at loggerheads
word.example: e.g. The creation of animal-human hybrid embryos for scientific research received bipartisan support from the then opposing leaders David Cameron and Gordon Brown.
word.etymology: from the Latin bi: two, and partire: to part

word.name: blandishment
word.meaning: a pleasant utterance to persuade someone to do something
word.example: e.g. Fidel Castro persuaded Graham Greene to campaign on his behalf against the US government by directing blandishments towards the writer.
word.etymology: from the Latin blandus: soft, smooth; from blandiri: to flatter

word.name: boulevardier
word.meaning: a socialite who is well-off and fashionable
word.example: e.g. With a long list of celebrity friends, hotel heiress Paris Hilton is a noted boulevardier.
word.etymology: from the French boulevardier: a person who frequents boulevards (which are wide city streets lined with trees, commonly found in the most gentrified areas).

word.name: bowdlerise
word.meaning: to cut off material considered unsuitable (from a work), especially with the result that the work becomes less powerful
word.example: e.g. The censors bowdlerised the film The Texas Chainsaw Massacre before clearing it for release.
word.etymology: bowdlerise derives from the name of Dr Thomas Bowdler (1754-1825), who in 1818 published a severely edited version of Shakespeare. As he lived in a prudish age, Bowdler knew that there would be a market for a sanitised version of Shakespeare's work - a version suitable for women and children. Bowdler called his work 'The Family Shakespeare' and it was a big success. Today, we continue to refer to any work of art that has been pared down by a censor as being bowdlerised.

word.name: braggadocio
word.meaning: boasting and swaggering
word.example: e.g. In his last film, The Misfits, Clark Gable insisted on doing hos own stunts, including being dragged by a horse; this braggadocio led to a fatal heart attack.
word.etymology: braggadocio derives from the name of Braggadocchio, a character in a poem called The Fairie Queen that was published in 1590 by Edmund Spenser to celebrate Queen Elizabeth 1. The character Braggadocchio was famous for his boasting and vain nature and we still use the word braggadocio today to refer to any behaviour of this type.

word.name: bulwark
word.meaning: something or someone that acts as a barricade
word.example: e.g. Cherie Blair found he husband's soothing comments a bulwark against harsh articles by journalists.
word.etymology: from the Middle High German Bollwerk, from Bohle: plank, and Werk: work; a bulwark literally means 'a defensive wall'.

word.name: bumptious
word.meaning: offensively self-assertive
word.example: e.g. Chat show hosts cannot afford to be too bumptious, as they must allow their guests to dominate the conversation.
word.etymology: from the 19th century, derived from 'bump'; a humerous coinage on the pattern of 'fractious'

word.name: burlesque
word.meaning: humour resulting from a comically exaggerated portrayal; OR a variety show involving undressing to music
word.example: e.g. Some comedians make a living out of the burlesque by imitating the voices of politicians.
word.etymology: from the Latin burlesco, from burla: mockery

word.name: Byronic
word.meaning: (of a man) dark and enigmatic in an attractive way
word.example: e.g. In the film Four Weddings and a Funeral, Hugh Grant plays a Byronic lothario.
word.etymology: Byronic derives from the name of Lord Byron (1788-1824), an English poet famously described by Lady Caroline Lamb as 'mad, bad and dangerous to kow' because of his womanising and risk-loving nature. It is appropriate then that Byron is today best known for his poem Don Juan, which describes the exploits of a serial philanderer; when we use the word Byronic today, we evoke Lord Byron's dangerous air that so enthralled women.

word.name: Byzantine
word.meaning: (of an administration) highly complex and sometimes devious
word.example: e.g. Most people find the UK government's tax system to be Byzantine.
word.etymology: The Byzantine Empire was the name for the Roman Empire between the 4th and 15th centuries AD. The Byzantine Empire was vast and sprawling and hence required a complex system of government, with thousands of different types of bureaucrats, all wearing different hats and outfits to denote their rank; it's no surprise that, in such as competitive environment, the most successful politicians were marked by their deviousness. Today, when we refer to an administration as Byzantine, we evoke this sense of unfathomable complexity as well as the deviousness of its creators.

word.name: cabal
word.meaning: a secret political group
word.example: e.g. On the many occasions that his leadership was under threat, Gordon Brown moved quickly to disband the cabal responsible.
word.etymology: from the French cabal: society.

word.name: cadence
word.meaning: a drop in the intensity of the voice at the end of a sentence
word.example: e.g. You can listen to Dame Judi Dench for hours because her voice is full of soothing cadences.
word.etymology: from the Latin cadere: to fall; the collection of notes comprising the close of a musical phrase.

word.name: cadre
word.meaning: a small group of people trained for a specific role
word.example: e.g. The SAS is an elite cadre of army troops.
word.etymology: from the Latin quandrus: a square

word.name: callisthenics
word.meaning: gymnastic exercises which have as their aims fitness and grace
word.example: e.g. The biggest-selling fitness video of all time, Jane Fonda's Workout, shows the actress performing her callisthenics regime.
word.etymology: from the Greek kallos: beauty, and sthenos: strength

word.name: callow
word.meaning: (of a young person) naive
word.example: e.g. The 11-year-old Audrey Hepburn carried messages for the Dutch Resistance hidden in her shoes: she looked so callow that the Nazis never suspected her.
word.etymology: from the Latin calvus: bald

word.name: cant
word.meaning: language specific to one group of people and looked down on by others; OR a hypocritical sermon
word.example: e.g. At the Oscars, the woman who wins 'Best Actress' usually embarks on an effusive cant that is customary at such events.
word.etymology: from the Latin cantare: to sing

word.name: carapace
word.meaning: a protective shell
word.example: e.g. People who are bullied have to develop a carapace in order to survive.
word.etymology: from the French carapace: a tortoise shell; a carapace is literally 'the hard upper shell of a tutle'.

word.name: careen
word.meaning: to move fast but in an uncontrolled way in one direction
word.example: e.g. James Dean died when a car careened into his own on State Route 46 in California.
word.etymology: from the Latin carina: a keel (which is a kind of ship)

word.name: carious
word.meaning: (of teeth and bone) rotted away
word.example: e.g. When talking, Oscar Wilde used to put one hand over his mouth to disguise his carious teeth from his interlocutor.
word.etymology: 1670s, from French carieux (16c.), from Latin cariosus "full of decay," from caries "rottenness, decay"

word.name: carnivalesque
word.meaning: involving a fun and uproarious mix
word.example: e.g. After England won the 2003 Rugby World Cup, a carnivalesque atmosphere reigned in London.
word.etymology: The word carnivalesque is the adjective from the noun 'carnival', which is a period of celebration that takes place in Roman Catholic countries in the weeks before Lent (i.e. January and February). For Catholics, Lent is a time of austerity when luxuries such as meat are renounced - hence the etymology of the word carnival that derives from the Latin carne vale, meaning 'farewell to meat'; as the carnival is the last chance to celebrate and indulge oneself before Lent's rigours. Processions and masked dancers characterise a carnival and when we use the word carnivalesque, we refer to this spirit of celebration.

word.name: Cassandra
word.meaning: someone who correctly predicts disaster but whom no one listens to
word.example: e.g. no one would listen to the few economists who in 2007 warned the world was about to enter a recession; but these Cassandras sadly proved only too accurate in their predictions.
word.etymology: Cassandra was in Greek mythology the daughter of the Trojan king Priam. Apollo took a shrine to the beautiful Cassandra and gave her the power of prophecy. When it became clear that Cassandra did not return Apollo's love, Apollo became angry and turned his gift into a curse by causing her prophecies, though still true, to be ignored by everyone. Today, we continue to describe as a Cassandra anyone who correctly predicts a catastrophe - such as the recent credit crunch - but is not listened to.

word.name: caustic
word.meaning: sarcastic in a particularly angry way
word.example: e.g. Judy Garland, start of The Wizard of Oz, gave her own mother the caustic title 'the real-life Wicked Witch of the West'.
word.etymology: from the Greek kaustos: combustible; caustic literally means 'able to corrode organic matter by chemical action'.

word.name: cavalcade
word.meaning: a formal line of people or objects moving together
word.example: e.g. At Elvis Presley's funeral, the cavalcade included 16 white Cadillacs and one white hound dog.
word.etymology: A cavalcade literally refers to a procession of people on horseback who gather to commemorate an historical event; the riders often travel huge distances in the process. The etymology of the word cavalcade reflects this equine connection, deriving as it does from the Italian 'cavalcare', meaning 'to ride'.

word.name: caveat emptor
word.meaning: the principle that it is the buyer alone who is responsible for ensuring that something purchased is of good quality
word.example: e.g. When a customer drives of with an old car that has been made to look like a new one, the car salesman thinks to himself: 'caveat emptor'.
word.etymology: from the Latin caveat emptor: let the buyer beware.

word.name: cerulean
word.meaning: blue like a cloudless sky
word.example: e.g. It is enjoyable to go for a stroll when the sun is bright and the sky cerulean.
word.etymology: from the Latin caeruleus: sky blue

word.name: ceteris paribus
word.meaning: assuming other conditions remain unchanged
word.example: e.g. Rising unemployment will, ceteris paribus, lead to a weaker economy.
word.etymology: from the Latin ceteris paribus: with other things being the same

word.name: chicanery
word.meaning: deception
word.example: e.g. Investors did not become aware of Bernard Madoff's chicanery until it was too late.
word.etymology: from the French chicancer: to quibble

word.name: chimera
word.meaning: a thing that is forever desired but not achievable
word.example: e.g. Due to our responsibilities to others, we must all accept that absolute personal liberty is a chimera.
word.etymology: chimera derives from the Greek word khimaira, which was in Greek mythology a monster that had a lion's head, a goat's body, and a serpent's tail. Such an animal does not of course exist in reality - and today chimera retains this sense of something that is an impossible dream that will never become a reality.

word.name: chrysalis
word.meaning: a stage involving preparation
word.example: e.g. The young Al Pacino spent a year with two aunts whose deafness forced him to gesticulate; this proved a good chrysalis for his extravagant acting style.
word.etymology: from the Greek khrusos: gold (because of the golder colour of the pupae of some species); a chrysalis literally means 'the discarded hard outer case of a quiescent insect pupa of a butterfly'.

word.name: cineaste
word.meaning: a lover of films
word.example: e.g. Before writing scripts, Quentin Tarantino worked in a DVD rental store, which was the perfect job for a cineaste like him.
word.etymology: from the French cine (from cinema), on the pattern of enthousiaste: enthusiast.

word.name: cipher
word.meaning: a person who is insignificant
word.example: e.g. As a constitutional monarch, the Queen does not interfere with the running of government but she does work hard for the country and is no mere cipher.
word.etymology: late 14c., "arithmetical symbol for zero," from Old French cifre "nought, zero," Medieval Latin cifra, with Spanish and Italian cifra, ultimately from Arabic sifr "zero," literally "empty, nothing," from safara "to be empty;" loan-translation of Sanskrit sunya-s "empty." The word came to Europe with Arabic numerals. Originally in English "zero," then "any numeral" (early 15c.), then (first in French and Italian) "secret way of writing; coded message" (a sense first attested in English 1520s), because early codes often substituted numbers for letters. Klein says Modern French chiffre is from Italian cifra.

word.name: circumlocutory
word.meaning: using many words when there is no need
word.example: e.g. As standard conversatin with Fidel Castro is reported to last hours because the Cuban leader is so circumlocutory.
word.etymology: from the Latin circumlocutio, from circum: around, and locutio: speech.

word.name: cirrus cloud
word.meaning: a cloud with threads around it
word.example: e.g. Einstein had white hair that surrounded his head like a cirrus cloud.
word.etymology: from the Latin cirrus, a curl

word.name: clarion call
word.meaning: a call for action
word.example: e.g. Barrack Obama's election campaign speeches included a clarion call for change.
word.etymology: from the Latin clarus: clear; a clarion call literally refers to a blast from a 'clarion', which is a shrill war trumpet.

word.name: cleave
word.meaning: to become extremely emotionally involved with (someone)
word.example: e.g. To fall in love at first sight is to cleave instantly to another person.
word.etymology: from the Old English clifian: to stick. Note that cleave has a secondary meaning (which is the direct opposite); to split something asunder, using force.

word.name: climacteric
word.meaning: a period when events of huge significance occur
word.example: e.g. The time surrounding the invasion of Iraq was the climacteris of Tony Blair's Prime Ministership.
word.etymology: from the Greek klimakter: a critical period.

word.name: coda
word.meaning: an ending
word.example: e.g. Elvis Presley received more that 19,000 uppers and downers from his doctor during the two years before he died: this was a sad coda to the star's life.
word.etymology: from the Latin cauda: tail

word.name: compere
word.meaning: the main presenter of a show, responsible for introducing others
word.example: e.g. When his mother's voice gave out, the five-year-old Charlie Chaplin finished her song after being ushered on by the compere.
word.etymology: from the French compere: a godfather.

word.name: concatenation
word.meaning: a series of things that are linked as if in a chain
word.example: e.g. Andy Warhol sometimes produced paintings by having his dog urinate on the canvas; the critics lauded the resulting concatenations of yellow.
word.etymology: c.1600, from Late Latin concatenationem (nominative concatenatio) "a linking together," noun of action from past participle stem of concatenare "to link together," from com- "together" (see com-) + catenare, from catena "a chain"

word.name: concomitant
word.meaning: a phenomenon that goes hand in hand with something
word.example: e.g. Diseases such as psoriasis are often concomitants to stress.
word.etymology: from the Latin concomitari, from con: together with, and comitari: to accompany (from the Latin comes: companion)

word.name: conflation
word.meaning: the act of melding two of more ideas into one
word.example: e.g. When Ben Afleck and Jennifer Lopez were an item, journalists used to refer to the couple by the conflation of 'Bennifer'

word.name: congeries
word.meaning: a messy collection
word.example: e.g. The competitors on the TV show Big Brother are from a congeries of backgrounds.
word.etymology: from the Latin congeries: a heap, from congerere: to heap up.

word.name: congruous
word.meaning: harmonious
word.example: e.g. It seems congruous that William Shakespeare dies on the 23rd April - for that is also the day he was born.
word.etymology: from the Latin congruere: to agree

word.name: conquistador
word.meaning: a person who sets out in search of adventure
word.example: e.g. Society's double standards mean that promiscuous men are lauded as conquistadors whilst promiscuous women are viewed as sluts.
word.etymology: conquistador means 'conquerer' in both Spanish and Portuguese. Today, the term conquistador is used to denote a conqueror of any kind.

word.name: consigliere
word.meaning: someone who advises
word.example: e.g. Before Henry VIII turned on him and chopped off his head, Sir Thomas More was consigliere to the king.
word.etymology: from the Italian consigliere: adviser.

word.name: continuum
word.meaning: a continuous sequence in which adjacent elements are very similar to each other, but the extremes are polar opposites
word.example: e.g. Alfred Kingsley believed that human sexuality forms a continuum, with complete heterosexuality at one end and complete homosexuality at the other.
word.etymology: from the Latin continuus: uninterrupted

word.name: contrail
word.meaning: the streak of white that a plane leaves behind it
word.example: e.g. The jet passed overhead, leaving a contrail in the sky.
word.etymology: contrail is an abbreviation of the 1940s expression 'condensation trail'

word.name: contumely
word.meaning: insulting treatment
word.example: e.g. A judge will not stand for contumely from a witness in court.
word.etymology: from the Latin contumelia: an insult, from con: (an intensifying prefix), and tumere: to swell up

word.name: cornucopia
word.meaning: an overflowing supply of pleasant things
word.example: e.g. Guests at weddings can expect to be served a cornucopia of food.
word.etymology: cornucopia means in Latin 'a horn of plenty' (conu copiae); from the 5th century BC, this was a symbol of food and abundance. The following Greek myth explains why it is that a goat's horn has become associated with a surfeit of good things. When the god Zeus was young, he used to play with a goat, whose horn he broke off one day by accident; to make amends, the god returned the horn to the goat, but in an improved form, for it was imbued with magical powers that meant whoever possessed it got whatever they wished for. Hence the horn came to be depicted by the Greeks as bursting with fruits and flowers and other treats that people desired; today we continue to use the word cornucopia to refer to any bountiful display of food and goodies.

word.name: corollary
word.meaning: something that naturally follows
word.example: e.g. People who have cataracts in their eyes literally see red: in fact the reddish tone of Monet's paintings is a corollary of his suffering from this condition.
word.etymology: from the Latin corollarium: money paid for a garland.

word.name: coruscating
word.meaning: (of light or of humour) sparkling
word.example: e.g. American wit H. L. Mencken once said, 'On one issue at least, men and women agree: they both distrust women'. What coruscating humour!
word.etymology: 1705, from Latin coruscatus, past participle of coruscare "to vibrate, glitter," perhaps from PIE *(s)ker- (2) "leap, jump about" (cf. scherzo). Related: Coruscated; coruscating.

word.name: costive
word.meaning: (of someone's character) niggardly; (of speech or movement) slow
word.example: e.g. Henry VIII became obese in his old age and later portraits of the monarch show him looking positively costive.
word.etymology: from the Old French costive: constipated (itself derived from the Latin constipatus: pressed together); costive literally means constipated.

word.name: coterie
word.meaning: a small group of people with a common goal
word.example: e.g. Elvis Presley was accompanied everywhere by the 'Memphis Mafia': his coterie of bodyguards and helpers.
word.etymology: from the French cotier: an organisation of peasants holding land owned by a feudal lord.

word.name: coup de grace
word.meaning: a fatal blow that finishes off a wounded animal
word.example: e.g. For a discontented wife, the discovery that her husband has been unfaithful is usually the coup de grace for the marriage.
word.etymology: from the French coup de grace: a stroke of grace

word.name: covey
word.meaning: a small crowd of people
word.example: e.g. As Tom Cruise arrived at the première of Mission Impossible, a covey of photographers snapped away.
word.etymology: from the Old French covee: a brood; a 'covey' is literally 'a small flock of birds'.

word.name: cowlick
word.meaning: a clump of hair at the back of the head that refuses to be straightened but sticks up straight as licked by a cow
word.example: e.g. The hairdo of cartoon character Tintin consists of one giant cowlick

word.name: crapulent
word.meaning: nauseous due to overindulgence
word.example: e.g. The wide girth of the older Marlon Brando spoke of a man who had enjoyed many a crapulent evening.
word.etymology: from the Latin crapula: inebriation.

word.name: craven
word.meaning: so timid as to be cowardly
word.example: e.g. Charlie Chaplin failed to server in World War 1 - not because he was craven, but because the army rejected him for being too small
word.etymology: from the Old French cravante, past participle of cravanter: to crush

word.name: cri de coeur
word.meaning: a cry from the heart
word.example: e.g. Princess Diana's TV interview with Martin Bashir - when she discussed the constrictions of royal life - was interpreted as a cri de coeur by the public.

word.name: cumulus
word.meaning: a large cloud composed of wispy clouds mixed together
word.example: e.g. On entering the cumulus, the pilot of the helicopter couldn't see a thing.
word.etymology: from the Latin cumulus: heap

word.name: cupola
word.meaning: a small dome that sits on top of a roof of a larger dome
word.example: e.g. Adorning the curved roof of the main dome of St Paul's Cathedral is a celebrated cupola.
word.etymology: from the Latin cupula: small cask

word.name: cursive
word.meaning: written in joined up handwriting
word.example: e.g. As a boy Hitchcock was obsessed with locomotives: the floor of his room was strewn with train timetables copied out in primitive cursive.
word.etymology: from the Latin currere: to run

word.name: de facto
word.meaning: in fact
word.example: e.g. Colonel Gaddafi has been the de facto leader of Libya since a coup in 1969.
word.etymology: from the Latin de facto: of fact

word.name: defray
word.meaning: to give money to cover (an expense)
word.example: e.g. If you are unemployed, the government will pay you a jobseeker's allowance to defray your outgoings.
word.etymology: from the French defrayer, from de: (expressing removal), and frai: cost

word.name: deleterious
word.meaning: destructive
word.example: e.g. Serial killer Fred West had violent rages, resulting from a motorbike accident that was deleterious to his brain.
word.etymology: from the Greek deleterios: noxious

word.name: Delphic
word.meaning: (of a pronouncement) purposefully unclear
word.example: e.g. After being charged for kicking out at opposition fans, footballer Eric Cantona called a press conference to deliver the following Delphic pronouncement: 'when the seagulls follow the trawler, it is because they think sardines will be thrown into the sea'
word.etymology: Delphic has its derivation in the ancient Greek oracle at Delphi, whose priestess was said to have the power of prediction; however, her pronouncements were so ambiguous that it was very hard to work out what she meant. For example, the oracle once warned a warrior called Lysander to watch out for: 'a serpent...craftily creeping up behind you...'. Lysander was presumably ever alert for snakes after that but in the end was killed by a man who was standing being him at the time and who had a snake on his shield - so the oracle's warning, although truthful in a way, wasn't really helpful. Today we use the term Delphic to evoke any pronouncement that is similarly hard to understand.

word.name: demimonde
word.meaning: a group of people on the periphery of society
word.example: e.g. Unlicensed cab drivers form part of the demimonde of illegal workers in the UK.
word.etymology: demimonde is a French expression meaning 'half-world'; in 19th-century France the term referred to those women who were shunned by society because they lived off their wealthy lovers to whom they were not married. Today, society is more tolerant of such situatios and so the term demimonde no longer refers to women in this position, but continues to be used of people who are on the fringes of society, such as workers who are in the UK illegally.

word.name: demotic
word.meaning: relating to everyday languages
word.example: e.g. Dan Brown writes forcefully in demotic English and this in part explains the huge success of his book The Davinci Code
word.etymology: from the Greek demotikos: popular

word.name: denouement
word.meaning: the climax of several actions, when the outcome becomes clear
word.example: e.g. Superman always triumphs over Lex Luthor in the denouement of the comic strips.
word.etymology: from the French denouer: to unknot

word.name: depredation
word.meaning: an act of looting
word.example: e.g. After some would-be blackmailers attempted a depredation of Charlie Chaplin's corpse, his family reburied his body under six feet of concrete.
word.etymology: from the Latin depraedari: to plunder

word.name: deracinate
word.meaning: to take something by the roots and tear it out; to alienate someone from their natural environment
word.example: e.g. Model Claudia Schiffer, who was born in Germany but now lives in England, is always photographed smiling: she never looks deracinated
word.etymology: from the French deraciner, from de: (expressing removal), and racine: root

word.name: desultory
word.meaning: jumping from one thing to another
word.example: e.g. The inebriated diner can have difficulty following a desultory dinner party conversation.
word.etymology: from the Latin desultor: vaulter, from the verb desilire: to jump down.

word.name: deus ex machina
word.meaning: an event that comes out of the blue and changes the outcome of a story
word.example: e.g. In the Mel Gibson film Apocolypto, the hero is saved from human sacrifice by the deus ex machine of a solar eclipse.
word.etymology: deus ex machina derives from the Greek term theos ek mekhane (meaning 'god from the machinery') and referred to those actors who, because they represented gods, were suspended above the stage in Greek theatres. Eventually these actors would be lowered down and intervene in the events on the stage, thus bringing about the plays ending. Today, we continue to use the term deus ex machina to refer to any device that appears from nowhere to end a film, play, or novel.

word.name: dialectic
word.meaning: the contradiction between two opposing forces viewed as the determining factor in their continuing interaction
word.example: e.g. The tension between the human tendency to sin and the desire for salvation is the dialectic that fascinated novelist Graham Greene.
word.etymology: from the Greek dialektike: debate

word.name: diaspora
word.meaning: the scattering of any people outside their homeland; OR the people who have been thus scattered
word.example: e.g. The 21-year-old Arnold Schwarzenegger came to the US in the 1960s: he was part of a diaspora from Europe at that time.
word.etymology: from the Greek dia: across, and speirin: to scatter (hence diasperein: to disperse)

word.name: dichotomy
word.meaning: a contrast between two things that are polar opposites
word.example: e.g. Bestsetlling authors like John Grisham are used to the dichotomy of being very popular with the public but sometimes unpopular with the critics.
word.etymology: from the Greek dikhotomia, from dikho: in two, and tomia: cutting (from temnein: to cut)

word.name: Dickensian
word.meaning: bringing to mind the novels of Charles Dickens (especially in evoking the themes of poverty and exploitation)
word.example: e.g. In one Dickensian scene from Roald Dahl's book Matilda, a cruel headmistress beats the girl Matilda
word.etymology: Dickensian refers to the novels of Charles Dickens, which were works of social commentary, as the author was committed to exposing poverty in Victorian society. The publicity unleashed by Dicken's novel Oliver Twist (1838), for example, led to the eventual dismantlement of a slum called Jacob's Island that was the basis for the story. Today we continue to use the term Dickensian to refer to any work that draws attention to poverty and social inequality.

word.name: dictum
word.meaning: a short statement that expresses a universal truth; OR a pronouncement from an official source
word.example: e.g. Warren Beatty is discreet about his romances, citing the dictum: 'Obviously my sex life is not mine alone to talk about'.
word.etymology: from the Latin dictum: something said, neuter past participle of dicere: to say

word.name: didactic
word.meaning: in the style of a patronising teacher
word.example: e.g. Readers prefer novels that have a subtly message rather than a didactic ending.
word.etymology: from the Greek didaktikos, from didaskein: to teach

word.name: diktat
word.meaning: an order imposed by a ruler despite objections from his people
word.example: e.g. Tyrants issue diktats on a whim
word.etymology: from the Latin dictatum: something dictated

word.name: dilatory
word.meaning: slow to take action (often purposefully so)
word.example: e.g. Alfred Hitchcock was awarded a knighthood but died before the Queen could present it to him because he was so dilatory in arranging to receive it.
word.etymology: from the Latin dilatorius: delaying

word.name: Dionysian
word.meaning: relating to the realms of sexual and emotional gratification
word.example: e.g. Hugh Hefner, owner of Playboy magazine, is known for his parties that the media depict as Dionysian.
word.etymology: Dionysian derives from the name of Dionysus, who in Greek mythology was the god of wine and ecstasy: hence the word Dionysian today refers to displays of intoxication and sensual indulgence. Note that Dionysus had a brother, Apollo, who was the exact opposite; when we describe someone as 'Apollonian', we mean that they embody Apollo's calm and disciplined nature. (Bacchus was the name given to Dionysus by the Romans)

word.name: dirge
word.meaning: a lament for the dead
word.example: e.g. At Michael Jackson's funeral, the mourners were moved to tears by the dirge sung by Stevie Wonder.
word.etymology: from the Latin dirige! (imperitive): direct!

word.name: disburse
word.meaning: (of money) to pay out
word.example: e.g. The government collects taxes then disburses this money, directing it to public services such as the NHS.
word.etymology: from the Old French desbourser, from des: (expressing removal), and bourse: purse

word.name: disport oneself
word.meaning: to enjoy oneself without inhibitions
word.example: e.g. In advertisements for holidays, models are often pictured disporting themselves on sunlit beaches.
word.etymology: from the Old French desporter, from des: away, and porter: to carry

word.name: disquisition
word.meaning: a long speech on a subject
word.example: e.g. Martin Luther King was renowned for his public disquisitions on civil rights.
word.etymology: from the Latin disquisitio: investigation, based on quaerere: to seek.

word.name: dissemble
word.meaning: to hide one's true motives
word.example: e.g. When someone asks 'How are you?', people who have the flu often dissemble and say 'Fine, thanks' rather than discuss their ailment.
word.etymology: from the Latin dissimulare: to disguise

word.name: dissimulate
word.meaning: to hide one's true thoughts
word.example: e.g. Faced with a large hotel bill, Errol Flynn feigned appendicitis: he had no compunction about dissimulating.
word.etymology: 1530s, from Latin dissimulatus, past participle of dissimulare "to disguise, hide, conceal, keep secret," from dis- (see dis-) + simulare (see simulate). Related: Dissimulated; dissimulating.

word.name: dissipate
word.meaning: to disappear (via dispersal); OR to cause to disappear
word.example: e.g. Once he'd stopped boxing, Mike Tyson found an alternative way to dissipate his energy: by working out at the gym
word.etymology: from the Latin dissipare: to scatter

word.name: distend
word.meaning: to swell due to a force from inside
word.example: e.g. When pregnant with twins, actress Angelina Jolie had a noticeably distended belly
word.etymology: from the Latin distendere: to stretch out, from dis: apart, and tendere: to stretch

word.name: diuretic
word.meaning: a drug that causes one to pass water more frequently
word.example: e.g. Alcohol and coffee are the most commonly used diuretics
word.etymology: from the Greek dia: through, and ouron: urine (hence diourein: to urinate)

word.name: doctrinaire
word.meaning: stubbornly insisting on applying a doctrine
word.example: e.g. Detractors of the Catholic Church say it is doctrinaire in sexual matters.
word.etymology: from the Latin doctrina: teaching, from docere: to teach

word.name: Doric
word.meaning: relating to classical order of architecture, characterised by a thick grooved column, topped by a rounded moulding and then a square
word.example: e.g. In the grounds of English country estates, you often find streams with Doric temples nearby
word.etymology: from the Greek Dorios: of Doris; which refers to the people of Doris who entered central Greece from the north in c.1100BC, and later colonised southern Italy.

word.name: doublethink
word.meaning: the ability to simultaneously believe in two ideas that contradict each other, while wilfully ignoring this contradiction
word.example: e.g. Critics say the Chinese government's statement - that 'China's internet is open and managed in accordance with the law' - is an example of doublethink.
word.etymology: doublethink is a concept invented by George Orwell in his novel Nineteen Eighty-Four. Nineteen Eighty-Four describes a totalitarian government which exercises control over its subject via propaganda. Yet the risk remains for the ruling regime that the disgust felt by its own officials at this use of propaganda might lead to the collapse of the system. This is the reason that the ruling regime uses reality control to ensure everyone - even its own officials - remains wilfully ignorant of contradictions within the regime's use of propaganda. One of the reality control devices that officials are encouraged to use is doublethink, which, Orwell tells us, is the ability to hold 'two contradictory beliefs in one's mind simultaneoulsy' while believing both to be correct. An example in the book is when civil servants rewrite government history and are then able to believe wholeheartedly in this new version of history that they themselves have just created. Today, we use the work doublethink to refer to any instance of someone wilfully ignoring contradictions in a belief system.

word.name: dovish
word.meaning: (of a person) advocating peace
word.example: e.g. Ghandi did so much to promote peace that he is still considered the most dovish politician of all time.
word.etymology: dovish is an adjective deriving from 'dove', which is traditionally seen as a bird of peace due to its white feathers and cooing voice; hence, for example, the Christian faith's depiction of the Holy Spirit as a dove. Today, when we call someone dovish, we mean that person advocates peaceful policies in foreign affairs.

word.name: ductile
word.meaning: able to be guided
word.example: e.g. Bing Crosby used to pin back his cauliflower ears with gum; his ears were sufficiently ductile to allow this.
word.etymology: from the Latin ductilis, from duct: led (from the verb ducere: to lead)

word.name: dyad
word.meaning: two individuals that are viewed as a pair
word.example: e.g. Psychologists spend much time discussing the parent-child dyad.
word.etymology: from the Greek duas: two

word.name: dyspeptic
word.meaning: having indigestion; OR having the irritability that results from indigestion
word.example: e.g. After a ten-course meal, most people look dyspeptic
word.etymology: from the Greek duspeptos: difficult to digest

word.name: dystopia
word.meaning: an imagined place that is nightmarish
word.example: e.g. In his documentary film An Inconvenient Truth, Al Gore warns us that we face dystopia unless we arrest global warming.
word.etymology: "imaginary bad place," 1868, apparently coined by J.S. Mill ("Hansard Commons"), from Greek dys- "bad, abnormal, difficult" (see dys-) + utopia. Related: Dystopian.

word.name: edict
word.meaning: an order from someone in office
word.example: e.g. 'Drink to me, drink to my health - you know I can't drink any more' was the last edict uttered by Pablo Picasso to his friends before he died.
word.etymology: from the Latin edicere, from e: out, and dicere: to say, tell

word.name: effluent
word.meaning: waste in liquid form that is emitted into a river
word.example: e.g. Effluent from factories contaminates rivers
word.etymology: from the Latin effluere: to flow out

word.name: effulgent
word.meaning: (of a light) shining strongly; OR (or a person's expression) emanating happiness
word.example: e.g. Mother Theresa's kindness found expression in her efulgent face
word.etymology: from the Latin effulgere: to shine brightly, from ex: out, and fulgere: to shine

word.name: egalitarian
word.meaning: relating to the premise that all people are equal
word.example: e.g. Social activists press for an egalitarian society
word.etymology: from the French egal: equal

word.name: egregious
word.meaning: so bad as to stand out
word.example: e.g. In September 1955, James Dean died from egregious injuries sustained in a car crash: his head was almost severed from his body.
word.etymology: from the Latin e: out, and grex: flock; egregious literally means 'standing out from the flock because the thing being described is so bad'

word.name: eldorado
word.meaning: an imaginary place full of gold sought in South America by 16th-century explorers; OR a lifelong goal
word.example: e.g. In the 19th century, many Europeans left to settle in the US, which they viewed as eldorado
word.etymology: eldorado - which means 'the golden one' (El Dorado) in Spanish - refers to a mythical city of gold that the 16th-century Spanish conquistadors were told existed in the newly discovered Americas. Spurred on by assurances from captive Indians that El Dorado overflowed with gold and precious gemstones, groups of Spaniards went out to find this place - but in vain, with many of them dying from diseases and attacks by the natives. Today, we use the word eldorado to signify a place where wealth can be acquired quickly (doubtless the founders of the world's biggest websites would describe the Internet as an eldorado). Eldorado can also be used to refer to a lifelong ambition (as as attaining happiness) and, in this way, it is similar to the word Shangir-La.

word.name: elagiac
word.meaning: (of a work of art) like a lament
word.example: e.g. The film Schindler's List, which covers the atrocities committed by the Nazis, has an elegiac tone.

word.name: elliptical
word.meaning: (of speech) lacking key words (but the sense can be worked out from the context)
word.example: e.g. In the film ET, it is easy to understand phrases such as 'ET go home' even though they are elliptical.
word.etymology: from the Greek elleiptikos: defective, from elleipein: to leave out.

word.name: elucidate
word.meaning: to explain (something) clearly
word.example: e.g. In his book A Brief History Of Time (1988), Stephen Hawking uses simple language to elucidate the subject of black holes.
word.etymology: from the Latin elucidare: to make clear, from e: out, and lucidus: light

word.name: emaciated
word.meaning: to be unusually lean
word.example: e.g. Due to a meagre diet most homeless people look emaciated.
word.etymology: from the Latin emaciare, from e (expressing a change of state), and macies: leanness

word.name: embonpoint
word.meaning: plumpness of person
word.example: e.g. Towards the end of his life Marlon Brando grew depressed and his embonpoint increased dramatically.
word.etymology: from the French en bon point: in good condition; embonpoint is a euphemism for fatness

word.name: emetic
word.meaning: a substance that brings about vomiting
word.example: e.g. The emperor Nero tried to keep his weight down by using emetics.
word.etymology: from the Greek emein: to vomit

word.name: eminence grise
word.meaning: a person who wields considerable power even through they have no official role
word.example: e.g. When Tony Blair was in power, the media depicted his unelected adviser Alistair Campbell as the eminence grise of the Labour Party.
word.etymology: eminence grise is a French expression literally meaning 'grey eminence'. The reason we use this term to describe a person who exerts a powerful but behind-the-scenes influence is because the first example of the controlling types to which this word refers was the grey-cloaked Pere Jospeh (1577-1638), who was the private secretary who controlled Cardinal Richelieu (who himself controlled King Louis XIII, the nominal ruler of France).

word.name: endemic
word.meaning: characteristic of people belonging to one particular area
word.example: e.g. Roget Federer epitomises the cool precision endemic to the Swiss.
word.etymology: from the Greek endemos: native, based on demos: people

word.name: enervate
word.meaning: to weaken (someone)
word.example: e.g. People involved in even minor car crashes feel enervated for weeks afterwards.
word.etymology: from the Latin enervare: to weaken (by extraction of the sinews)

word.name: emnity
word.meaning: hostility towards someone or something
word.example: e.g. When somebody accused him of being a vandal because he was signing copies of his own novels in a bookshop, Stephen King felt no emnity; he knew it was a simple misunderstanding.
word.etymology: from the Latin inimicus: enemy

word.name: ennui
word.meaning: the kind of dissatisfaction that arises when nothing exciting has happened for a while
word.example: e.g. Teenagers are moody because the chemical changes in their bodies ensure the feel ennui more than the rest of us.
word.etymology: from the French ennui: boredom

word.name: ephemeron
word.meaning: something that is short-lived
word.example: e.g. Charlie Chaplin is still well-known today: his fame was no ephemeron
word.etymology: from the Greek ephemeros: lasting only a day

word.name: epithet
word.meaning: a phrase that describes someone
word.example: e.g. In his body-building days, Arnold Schwarzenegger's powerful physique meant that he was known by the epithet of 'The Austrian Oak'
word.etymology: from the Greek epitheton, neuter of epithetos: attributed

word.name: eponymous
word.meaning: (of a person) giving their name to something
word.example: e.g. In the TV series Columbo, Peter Falk played the eponymous here detective
word.etymology: from the Greek epic: upon, and onyma, variant of onoma: name

word.name: ersatz
word.meaning: used as a poor substitute (for something else)
word.example: e.g. After his marriage to Marilyn Monroe ended, baseball star Joe DiMaggio pursued lookalikes of his wife; but he found no joy with these ersatz Marilyns.
word.etymology: 875, from German Ersatz "units of the army reserve," literally "compensation, replacement, substitute," from ersetzen "to replace," from Old High German irsezzen, from ir-, unaccented variant of ur- + setzen "to set" (see set (v.)). As a noun, from 1892.

word.name: ethereal
word.meaning: so delicate as to seem otherworldly
word.example: e.g. With her thin frame and light hair, Michelle Pfeiffer emits an ethereal impression.
word.etymology: from the Greek aither: the upper air

word.name: etiolated
word.meaning: looking sickly
word.example: e.g. The Brazilian beauty who calls herself Giselle has curves, differentiating her from the average etiolated supermodel.
word.etymology: etiolated was first used to refer to a plant that has become sickly and drawn-looking due to a lack of exposure to light. The word etiolated then evolved to describe humans in a similarly enfeebled state.

word.name: euphonic
word.meaning: sounding good
word.example: e.g. Elton John is rich because he has produced a series of highly euphonic melodies over the years and these have sold well.
word.etymology: from the Greek eu: well, and phone: sound

word.name: evanescent
word.meaning: vanishing fast
word.example: e.g. The four members of the pop group ABBA got married and then divorced; but sadly these two unions proved to be evanescent.
word.etymology: from the Latin evanescere: to disappear

word.name: eviscerate
word.meaning: to take away the core of something
word.example: e.g. Director Stanley Kubric was upset when is film A Clockwork Orange was eviscerated by the censors.
word.etymology: from the Latin eviscere: to disembowel, from e: out, and viscera: internal organs

word.name: excoriate
word.meaning: to criticise strongly
word.example: e.g. Peter Sutcliffe, the Yorkshire Ripper, is excoriated for his horrific murders of women.
word.etymology: from the Latin excoriare: to skin, from ex: out, and corium: skin; excoriate literally means 'to remove part of the surface of the skin'.

word.name: exculpate
word.meaning: to prove (that someone is) not guilty
word.example: e.g. After a high-profile criminal trial, O.J. Simpson was exculpated of the murder of his wife and her male companion.
word.etymology: 1650s, from Medieval Latin exculpatus, past participle of exculpare, from Latin ex culpa, from ex "from" (see ex-) + culpa ablative of culpa "blame, fault." Related: Exculpated; exculpating.

word.name: execrable
word.meaning: damnable
word.example: e.g. President Mugabe has allowed inflation to escalate; as a consequence many Zimbabweans live in execrable poverty.
word.etymology: from the Latin exsecrati: to curse (the inverse of sacrare: to dedicate)

word.name: exemplar
word.meaning: an outstanding example
word.example: e.g. In the UK, the Queen is a leading exemplar of selfless duty
word.etymology: from the Latin exemplum: a sample, imitation

word.name: exigent
word.meaning: demanding
word.example: e.g. After performing, Pavarotti could barely speak because the physical demands of singing were so exigent.
word.etymology: from the Latin exigere: to demand

word.name: expatiate
word.meaning: (of speech) to elaborate
word.example: e.g. On the TV show Richard and Judy, Judy frequently looked at the camera while Richard expatiated.
word.etymology: from the Latin exspatiari: to move beyond one's usual bounds, from ex: out, spatiari: to walk

word.name: expedient
word.meaning: (of an action) convenient, although possibly morally wrong
word.example: e.g. Critics of David Cameron say he pursues whichever policy is most politically expedient.
word.etymology: from the Latin expedire: to extricate, originally by freeing one's feet from being tied up (from ex: out, and pes, ped: foot)

word.name: expiate
word.meaning: to make up for (a sin)
word.example: e.g. Catholics believe that, with prayer and compensatory acts, their sins can be expiated.
word.etymology: from the Latin expiat: appeased by sacrifice, from the verb expiare, from ex: out, and piare, from pious: pious.

word.name: expostulate
word.meaning: to express strong objections
word.example: e.g. When Clark Gable failed his early film auditions because the studios considered his ears too floppy, he would expostulate at length.
word.etymology: from the Latin expostulare: to demand

word.name: expurgate
word.meaning: to remove matter deemed improper (from a work)
word.example: e.g. Serial womaniser Casanova kept one fingernail especially long so that he could use it to expurgate the wax in his ears.
word.etymology: from the Latin expurgare: to thoroughly cleanse, from ex: out, and purgare: to cleanse

word.name: extemporise
word.meaning: (of music or a speech) to perform spontaneously
word.example: e.g. Louis Armstrong, like every good jazz musician, was capable of extemporizing at will.
word.etymology: from the Latin ex tempore: (arising) out of the time

word.name: extirpate
word.meaning: to rip out by the roots and destroy
word.example: e.g. Before his conversion, St Paul was a Roman official devoted to extirpating Christianity.
word.etymology: from the Latin exstirpare, from ex: out, and stirps: a stem

word.name: factious
word.meaning: relating to a state of conflict within an organisation
word.example: e.g. After losing the general election the Labour Party became factious; Gordon Brown then quickly resigned.
word.etymology: from the Latin facere: to do

word.name: factotum
word.meaning: an employee who performs many tasks
word.example: e.g. In his book A Royal Duty, Paul Burrell wrote about his experiences as factotum to Princess Diana.
word.etymology: from the Latin facere: to do, and totum: the whole thing

word.name: fait accompli
word.meaning: a thing that has been settled before those affected hear about it
word.example: e.g. When one spouse decides to divorce the other, the decision is usually presented as a fait accompli.
word.etymology: from the French fait accompli: accomplished fact

word.name: fallacy
word.meaning: an incorrect belief
word.example: e.g. There is no evidence that a monster lurks in Loch Ness - its supposed existence is a fallacy.
word.etymology: from the Latin fallacia: deceit

word.name: fatuous
word.meaning: silly
word.example: e.g. Adults may find children's TV programme fatuous.
word.etymology: from the Latin fatuus: foolish

word.name: faux-naif
word.meaning: (of a work of art of a person) naive in an affected way
word.example: e.g. Agatha Christie's novels, detective Miss Marple lures murderers into a false sense of security with her faux-naif manner.
word.etymology: from the French faux: false, and naif: naive

word.name: febrile
word.meaning: excited in a nervy way
word.example: e.g. In 2008, Lehman Brothers went bust; this made stock markets febrile and share prices fluctuated violently.
word.etymology: from the Latin febris: fever; febrile literally means 'having the symptoms of a fever'

word.name: feckless
word.meaning: irresponsible and not considering others
word.example: e.g. A husband who walks out on his pregnant wife is feckless.
word.etymology: from the northern English dialect feck (from effeck, variant of 'effect').

word.name: fecund
word.meaning: capable of producing many offspring
word.example: e.g. An hourglass figure is attractive to a man because it shows that a woman is fecund.
word.etymology: from the Latin fecundus: fruitful

word.name: felicity
word.meaning: a pleasing manner of expression; OR the state of being happy
word.example: e.g. Barack Obama is famous for speaking with a felicity that no other politician can match.
word.etymology: from the Latin felicitas: happiness

word.name: fetid
word.meaning: smelling very unsavoury
word.example: e.g. When investigators opened the door to serial killer Ted Bundy's home; the fetid odour of decay assaulted them.
word.etymology: from the Latin fetere: to stink

word.name: fetishise
word.meaning: to develop an irrational devotion to (something)
word.example: e.g. The public fetishised the marriage between Princess Diana and Prince Charles because here beauty and his royalty made it a fairytale romance.
word.etymology: deriving from the Portuguese word feitico: a charm

word.name: finagle
word.meaning: to obtain (something) by roguish means
word.example: e.g. The media have suggested that Bernhard Madoff bought his large houses with money he had finagled from others.
word.etymology: from the Old French fornier: to deny

word.name: fissile
word.meaning: able to split apart with ease
word.example: e.g. It's hoped that any asteroid approaching Earth disintegrates before impact: but woe betide humanity if the asteroid is not fissile.
word.etymology: from the Latin fiss: split (from the verb findere: to split, cleave)

word.name: fissure
word.meaning: a state of discord
word.example: e.g. The writer Dostoevsky gambled away so much money that his wife had to pawn her wedding ring, causing fissures in the marriage.
word.etymology: from the Latin fissura: a cleft, from findere: to split, cleave; a fissure literally means 'a long narrow opening made by cracking'.

word.name: flaneur
word.meaning: someone who lounges around
word.example: e.g. Audrey Hepburn eventually abandoned films in favour of working for UNICEF because she had grown bored of being a flaneur.
word.etymology: from the French flaner: to lounge

word.name: flaxen
word.meaning: (esp. of hair) of the light yellow colour of dressed flax (which is a type of fibre)
word.example: e.g. Grace Kelly was renowned for her flaxen locks.
word.etymology: from the Old English fleax: cloth made with linen.

word.name: flotilla
word.meaning: a group moving together
word.example: e.g. An appearance on Oprah Winfrey's book club ensures an author sells millions more books because of the resulting flotilla of interested journalists.
word.etymology: With a navy, flotilla refers to a group of small warships of the same type, such as submarines or minesweepers. Today, flotilla is used most commonly to evoke the image of a small group of people moving around together.

word.name: flummery
word.meaning: hollow compliments
word.example: e.g. The Queen's speech is popular because people sense the Queen is speaking sincerely: it is far more than flummery coming out of her mouth.
word.etymology: flummery refers to a pudding consisting of stewed fruit thickened with cornflour. This pudding gained popularity in the 17th century when it was shaped by a mould and served to applause. However, its taste was bland and unimpressive. So it is that today we continue to use the word 'flummery' to refer to any applause that is meaningless or any praise that is hollow.

word.name: folderol
word.meaning: silly fussing
word.example: e.g. Barack Obama's daughters looked amused by their father's presidential inauguration ceremony and the attendant folderol.
word.etymology: from a nonsense refrain of 'fol-de-rol' in songs from the 19th century.

word.name: folie de grandeur
word.meaning: delusions of grandeur
word.example: e.g. To judge by the number of statues of himself he had built, Saddam Hussein suffered from folie de grandeur.
word.etymology: from the French folie: madness, from de: of, and grandeur: grandeur

word.name: foment
word.meaning: to stir up (on unpleasant sentiment)
word.example: e.g. Billionaire recluse Howard Hughes forbade his staff from talking to him lest they expel germs in his direction; this ban fomented resentment towards him.
word.etymology: from the Latin fomentum resentment towards him.

word.name: fontanelle
word.meaning: a gap between the bones of the skull in an infant, where the bone has not yet grown over
word.example: e.g. You have to make sure when patting a young baby's head not to press down on the fontanella because it is a very delicate area.
word.etymology: from the Old French fontanelle, the diminutive of fontaine: spring; this soft spot of a baby's head was meant to resemble the dent in the earth where a spring rises.

word.name: force majeure
word.meaning: to declare that an event is beyond one's control
word.example: e.g. As it was raining incessantly, the organisers of the cricket match called force majeure and cancelled the game.
word.etymology: from the French force majeure: greater force

word.name: fountainhead
word.meaning: the source of something
word.example: e.g. The Beatles remain a fountainhead of inspiration for many bands.
word.etymology: literally referring to a stream's source

word.name: friable
word.meaning: easily reduced to powder by the act of crumbling
word.example: e.g. You must be careful when arranging dried flowers because they are friable.
word.etymology: from the Latin friare: to crumble.

word.name: frond
word.meaning: a mass formed by strands of hair
word.example: e.g. Marilyn Monroe is famous for her blonde hair which tumbled from the head in fronds.
word.etymology: from the Latin frans, frondis: a leaf; a frond literally means 'the leaf of a palm, fern, or similar plant'.

word.name: fulminate against
word.meaning: to express violent protest about something
word.example: e.g. When a wife fulminates against her husband, he will often fight back.
word.etymology: fulminate derives from the Latin word for lightning (fulmen, fulmunis) and means 'to protest violently'; this is because, in Greek mythology, when the god Zeus became angry, he would hurl a thunderbolt at the person who had irked him. The verb fulminate has the following extra meanings: - (of lightning) to flash (in a literal sense - rather than in the metaphorical sense above) - (of a disease) to flare up e.g. The doctor operated on the patient at once to cut out the fulminating appendix.

word.name: gallimaufry
word.meaning: a messy jumble
word.example: e.g. Most high streets are composed of a gallimaufry of shops and restaurants.
word.etymology: from the archaic French galimafree: ragout

word.name: garrulous
word.meaning: too talkative, especially on matters that are unimportant
word.example: e.g. Einstein's parents at first thought he was retarded because he said nothing until the age of five; but Einstein grew into a garrulous adult.
word.etymology: 1610s, from Latin garrulus "talkative," from garrire "to chatter," from PIE root *gar- "to call, cry," of imitative origin (cf. Greek gerys "voice, sound," Ossetic zar "song," Welsh garm, Old Irish gairm "noise, cry"). Related: Garrulously; garrulousness.

word.name: gerrymander
word.meaning: to redefine an electoral constituency so as to favour one party
word.example: e.g. in the UK, politically neutral organisations define the boundaries of electoral constituencies so as to eliminate the risk of gerrymandering.
word.etymology: The verb gerrymander originated in the early 19th century, arising from the combination of the name of one Governor Elbridge Gerry of Massachusetts with the word 'salamander'. Seeing that his political party was about to lose an election, Governor Gerry signed a new bill into law that redrew the electoral boundaries to favour his party. This new area happened to include one district that was shaped like a salamander, a creature that looks like a newt. A journalist noted this resemblance and soon there appeared in The Boston Weekly Messenger a drawing of a salamander - but with claws and wings added to enhance the impression of evil at work - that was given the title The Gerry-mander (to evoke the name of the meddlesome Governor Gerry). Today we continue to use the word gerrymander to describe any attempt by a political party to draw up new voting districts to swing the vote its way.

word.name: ghoulish
word.meaning: referring to a person obsessed with death and tragedy
word.example: e.g. The sudden death of someone as well known as Diana Princess of Wales is of interest to everyone, not just to the ghoulish.
word.etymology: from the Arabic gul: a desert demon believed to rob graves and devour corpses.

word.name: gimcrack
word.meaning: badly made but attractive in a deceptive way
word.example: e.g. When on holiday people are often tempted to buy gimcrack gifts - such as engraved seashells - which they regret purchasing when they get home.
word.etymology: from the Middle English gibecrake: a kind of ornament

word.name: gimlet-eyed
word.meaning: having eyes with a penetrating stare
word.example: e.g. One reason for Daniel Craig being chosen to play James Bond was his gimlet-eyed gaze.
word.etymology: from the English word, gimlet: a tool for boring holes; gimlet-eyed literally means 'having eyes like a gimlet'

word.name: glacial
word.meaning: very slow (like the movement of a glacier, which is a mass of slow-moving ice formed from compacted snow on mountains)
word.example: e.g. Funeral hearses move at a glacial speed compared to normal traffic.
word.etymology: from the Latin glacialis: icy. It also has the following extra meaning: - very cold

word.name: glib
word.meaning: talking fluently but without sincerity
word.example: e.g. Jeeves creator P. G. Woodhouse used to live exclusively in ground floor flats so that he could avoid small talk with glib elevator operators.
word.etymology: from the Dutch, glibberig: slippery

word.name: gloaming
word.meaning: the time between daylight and darkness
word.example: e.g. The number of road accidents increases during the gloaming because many drivers haven't yet turned their lights on.
word.etymology: from the Old English glomung, from glom: twilight. gloaming is the early onset of twilight (the time immediately after sunset when the light is faint; dusk is the later, darker stage of twilight).

word.name: gnomic
word.meaning: (of an utterance) enigmatic and pithy
word.example: e.g. 'My wallpaper and I are fighting a duel to the death. One or other of us has to go,' was Oscar Wilde's gnomic deathbed utterance.
word.etymology: from the Greek gnomai: sayings, maxims.

word.name: Grand Guignol
word.meaning: drama that entertains but is horrific
word.example: e.g. The most famous example of Grand Guignol in recent times is the film Sweeney Todd starring Johnny Depp.
word.etymology: The English term Grand Guignol originates from the name of the French theatre Le Theatre du Grand-Guignol (The theatre of the Big Puppet), which was formed in Paris in 1897. This theatre was a place of gore, staging horror shows; the success of each performance was gauged by the number of people who fainted. After the all too real horrors of World War II, demand for artificial horror subsided and the theatre closed. However, we still use the word today to refer to any play or film which uses gory special effects to shock.

word.name: grass roots
word.meaning: ordinary people rather than those at the centre of major political activity
word.example: e.g. When Oliver Cromwell abolished Christmas in the 17th century and turned it into an ordinary working day, he should have predicted that the grass roots of his party would object to this.
word.etymology: The term grass roots was first used by a certain Senator Beveridge of Indiana, who said in 1912 of the Progressive Party that had just been formed. 'This party has come from the "grass roots". It has grown from the soil of people's hard necessities. Today, we continue to use the phrase grass roots to refer to any political movement that has arisen as a result of discontent amongst ordinary voters - rather than as a result of politician's machinations.

word.name: hagiography
word.meaning: a biography that idealises the person described, as if they were a saint
word.example: e.g. The book with the title The Rise of Boris Johnson suggests a hagiography of the politician but in fact offers a balanced view of the subject.
word.etymology: from the Greek hagios: holy, and graphe: writing; hagiography literally means 'the writing of the lives of the saints'

word.name: halycon
word.meaning: denoting a happy and peaceful time in the past
