word.example: e.g. Most people look back on their childhood as consisting of halycon days.
word.etymology: In Greek mythology, the halycon (halykon in Greek) was a type of kingfisher that built its nest by the sea. To explain how any bird could bring up its young by a noisy and raging sea, the Greeks attributed to this kingfisher the power to render the wind and the waves calm. So it is that today, when we refer to halycon days, we evoke a period of calm.

word.name: harmatia
word.meaning: a flaw that brings about the destruction of a hero
word.example: e.g. Marilyn Monroe's harmatia was a fondness for men in power: many say this lead to her death.
word.etymology: The term harmatia was first used by the ancient Greeks to describe an error in judgement. Nowadays, harmatia is used to mean something slightly different: a character's 'tragic flaw' that ultimately destroys him. A good example occurs in one of the most famous novels of the 20th century: The Great Gatsby (1925). Jay Gatsby's harmatia is his unreciprecated love for a married lady called Daisy; when Daisy runs over and kills a woman by accident, Gatsby claims it is he who was responsible and, as a result, is murdered by the victim's husband.

word.name: harbinger
word.meaning: something that heralds the approach of another
word.example: e.g. As a child, Oprah Winfrey played games interviewing the crows in her garden: this was the harbinger of her success as a chat show host.
word.etymology: The word harbinger derives from the French word herberger, which means 'someone who provides lodging' (itself originating from herberge, meaning 'lodging'). Later the woord came to mean 'a man who went ahead to find lodgings for an army' - hence 'a forerunner', and this sense persists today.

word.name: harpy
word.meaning: a woman known for her grasping nature
word.example: e.g. If an attractive young woman marries a rich old man, society is quick to label the woman a harpy.
word.etymology: A harpy was in Greek mythology a flying creature with a woman's head but a monster's body. Harpies would descend from the sky and snatch food from the hands of humans on the ground: It is for this reason that the literal meaning of harpy (harpazein - to snatch in Greek) is 'someone who snatches'. Today we continue to refer to any grasping woman as a harpy.

word.name: hawkish
word.meaning: advocating war or aggression
word.example: e.g. Towards the end of his life, Elvis Presley amassed an arsenal of weapons - including 32 handguns - because chronic drug abuse had made him hawkish.
word.etymology: hawkish derives from 'hawk', a warlike bird; the direct opposite is dovish.

word.name: heft
word.meaning: the amount of power that one wields
word.example: e.g. George Bush's detractors depicted him as lacking the intellectual heft for the Presidency.
word.etymology: heft derives from 'heft', the obsolete past participle of the verb 'heave'.

word.name: hegemony
word.meaning: leadership
word.example: e.g. With three successive league championships between 2007 and 2009, Manchester united's hegemony within English football is clear.
word.etymology: from the Greek hegemon: leader

word.name: heterogeneous
word.meaning: made up of diverse units
word.example: e.g. Aside from a love of tennis, it is hard to find commonality among the crowds at the Wimbledon tennis championships: they form a heterogeneous group.
word.etymology: The direct opposite of heterogeneous is homogeneous, meaning 'made up of units that exactly the same as each other'. For example, penguins are pretty much indistinguishable to humans; in other words, as far as we are concerned, these birds form a homogeneous mass.

word.name: hew to
word.meaning: to stick to
word.example: e.g. Steven Spielberg's films - Jaws, for example - all hew to his action-packed vision of story-telling.
word.etymology: deriving from the 19th-century phrase 'to hew to the line', meaning 'to cut evenly with a saw'; this reconciles the German root, hauen: 'to cut' with the seemingly contradictory English expression 'to hew to', meaning 'to stick to'.

word.name: hidebound
word.meaning: unwilling to adapt due to one's upbringing
word.example: e.g. In Romeo and Juliet, both sets of parents cannot accept the union of their progeny because they are hidebound by historical feuds with one another.
word.etymology: hidebound was first used in the 16th century to describe cattle that had been undernourished, which led to their skin clinging closely to their back and ribs (and in this sense, their innards were bound together by their hides alone). hidebound then evolved in meaning to refer to undernourished human beings, before assuming today's usage - which is 'undernourished in outlook' and thus 'unwilling to change'.

word.name: highfalutin
word.meaning: (of language) grand-sounding
word.example: e.g. Novels are divided into those that are commercial, such as The Divinci Code - and those that are considered highfalutin, such as Proust's works.
word.etymology: highfalutin derives from the words 'high' and 'fluting': together, these words mean 'to speak in a melodious way reminiscent of the sound of a flute'.

word.name: hinterland
word.meaning: a realm beyond the things that are known (about someone or something)
word.example: e.g. In the two bestsellers he wrote before he became President, Barack Obama discusses his religious beliefs and other areas of the hinterland.
word.etymology: from the German, hinter: behind, and land: land; hinterland literally refers to the uncharted areas beyond a river's banks.

word.name: hortatory
word.meaning: vigorously encouraging
word.example: e.g. While conducting, Tchaikovsky held onto his chin with one hand: he had a phobia that his head would roll off otherwise due to his hortatory hand movements.
word.etymology: from the Latin hortari: to exhort

word.name: hubris
word.meaning: excessive pride
word.example: e.g. Bernard Madoff showed hubris in believing he could deceive so many investors forever; nemesis came when his fraud was discovered and he was imprisoned for life.
word.etymology: hubris was the term given by the Greeks to describe the behaviour of anyone whose excessive pride led him or her to challenge the gods. Excessive pride is traditionally punished by the equal and opposite force of retributive justice; the Greeks called this power nemesis; the contemporary expression 'pride comes before a fall' also describes this relationship. So, such a display of hubris by Bernard Madoff - who thought he could fool all of the people all of the time - was always going to be punished by nemesis.

word.name: husband
word.meaning: (or resources) to use sparingly
word.example: e.g. Oprah Winfrey was born to a single teenage mother who had to husband the few resources she had.
word.etymology: from the Old Norse hus: a house

word.name: Hydra
word.meaning: a problem that is hard to conquer because it will not go away
word.example: e.g. Trying to stop the spread of AIDS in Africa is like trying to kill the Hydra; there may be short-lived successes but, sadly, the problem seems perennial.
word.etymology: The Lernaean Hydra was in Greek mythology a sea monster with many heads who guarded an underwater entrance to the Underworld. If one of its heads was chopped off, two would grow back in its place; but there was hope for anyone seeking to vanquish the Hydra in combat as only one of its heads was immortal. As one of his 12 labours, Hercules had to defeat the Hydra. He did this by chopping off each head, then by having his nephew cauterise each stump to prevent regrowth. Hercules then pushed a huge rock on top of the immortal head. Today, we continue to refer to a problem that seems impossible to overcome as a Hydra.

word.name: hyperbole
word.meaning: deliberate exaggeration for effect
word.example: e.g. When people exclaim 'over my dead body!', they are not talking about literally dying for a cause but are using hyperbole to make a point.
word.etymology: from the Greek huperbole: excess, from huper: above, and ballein: to throw

word.name: idee fixe
word.meaning: an idea that has become an obsession
word.example: e.g. Imelda Marcos accumulated as many pairs of shoes as possible: amassing footwear was an idee fixe for her.
word.etymology: from the French idee fixe: fixed idea

word.name: ideologue
word.meaning: a dogmatic follower of an ideology
word.example: e.g. Iran's status as a fundamentalist Islamic republic was cemented by the ideologue Ayatollah Khomeini (1900-1989).
word.etymology: from the Greek idea: form, and logos: word

word.name: idiosyncratic
word.meaning: (of a characteristic) peculiar to an individual
word.example: e.g. Jimmy Connor's double-handed backhand was a key part of his idiosyncratic style on the tennis court.
word.etymology: from the Greek idios: private, and sunkratos: mixed together.

word.name: imbroglio
word.meaning: a very messy and embarrassing situation
word.example: e.g. When his wife's younger sister died, Charles Dickens took the ring off the dead woman's finger and wore it until he died: this caused quite an imbroglio.
word.etymology: from the Italian, imbrogliare: to confuse

word.name: immanent
word.meaning: existing in
word.example: e.g. While we are all aware that death is immanent in life, we still find it hard to accept the thought of our own mortality.
word.etymology: from the Latin in: in, and manere: to remain

word.name: impassible
word.meaning: incapable of feeling hardship
word.example: e.g. Indian fakirs who walk barefoot across hot coals give the impression of being impassible.
word.etymology: from the Latin in: not, and pass: suffered (from the verb, pati)

word.name: impecunious
word.meaning: poor
word.example: e.g. Audrey Hepburn's grave is a small mound marked by a simple cross - to look at it, you might assume the actress was impecunious.
word.etymology: from the Latin im: not, and pecunia: money; impecunious literally means 'having no money'

word.name: impervious
word.meaning: not affected by
word.example: e.g From the age of eight, Mark Twain smoked on average 30 cigars a day until he died: he was impervious to doctor's advice to quit.

word.name: imprimatur
word.meaning: a person's guarantee that something is of good quality
word.example: e.g. Kim Jong-il's youngest son, Kim Jong-un, is expected to assume control of North Korea on his father's death because he enjoys his father's imprimatur.
word.etymology: imprimatur means in Latin, 'let it be printed'. Imprimatur at first described an official declaration by the Roman Catholic Church that a book contained no errors in matters of Catholic doctrine - and so could be read by the faithful. The word imprimatur today has a wider meaning, referring to a guarantee by anyone that something is up to scratch.

word.name: incandescent
word.meaning: burning with anger; OR of blindingly good quality
word.example: e.g. Isaac Newton was so absent-minded he once used his fiancée's finger to push down the tobacco in his pipe: this made her incandescent.
word.etymology: from the Latin incandescere: to glow; incandescent literally means 'emitting light as a result of being heated'

word.name: incendiary
word.meaning: tending to stir up trouble
word.example: e.g. Jeremy Paxman has made his incendiary comments about the deteriorating quality of Marks and Spencer's Y-fronts.
word.etymology: from the Latin incendere: to set fire to; incendiary literally means 'causing fires'

word.name: inchoate
word.meaning: just started and thus not in a final state
word.example: e.g. Monika Lewinsky must wonder what might have been had Bill Clinton not called off their affair when it was still inchoate.
word.etymology: from the Latin incohare: to begin

word.name: incongruous
word.meaning: not in harmony with the other elements of something
word.example: e.g. When Charlie Chaplin was 54, he married an 18-year-old girl; this age difference made the couple look incongruous
word.etymology: from the Latin incongruus, from in: not, and congruus: agreeing

word.name: indentured
word.meaning: (of a labourer) bound by a formal agreement
word.example: e.g. Some women form such close bonds with their mothers that they seem indentured to them.
word.etymology: from the Latin in: into, and dens, dent: a tooth; in indenture originally referred to a document that was indented; then to a sealed agreement binding an apprentice to his master.

word.name: indigent
word.meaning: impoverished
word.example: e.g. As a noted philanthropist, billionaire stock market trader George Soros donates money to the indigent.
word.etymology: from the Latin indigere: to need

word.name: ineffable
word.meaning: (of a sentiment) too great to be uttered in words
word.example: e.g. When the attend church, religious people speak of experiencing ineffable joy.
word.etymology: from the Latin ineffabilis. From in: not, and effabilis, from effari: to utter.

word.name: ineluctable
word.meaning: inescapable
word.example: e.g. After Lehman Brothers collapsed, a worldwide financial crisis became ineluctable.
word.etymology: from the Latin in: not, and eluctari: to struggle out.

word.name: in extremis
word.meaning: in a very troublesome situation
word.example: e.g. When the sailors were 50 miles from shore, a storm suddenly arose and they found themselves in extermis.
word.etymology: from the Latin in extermis: in the outermost parts.

word.name: infelicity
word.meaning: an unpleasing manner of expression; OR unhappiness
word.example: e.g. The speech of young children who are still learning how to talk is littered with infelicities.
word.etymology: from the Latin infelix: unhappy

word.name: infraction
word.meaning: a breaking of a rule
word.example: e.g. If any player other than the goalkeeper uses his hands on a football pitch, he is guilty of an infraction of the rules.
word.etymology: from the Latin infractio: a breaking, from infringere, from in: into, and frangere: to break.

word.name: inquisitorial
word.meaning: so prying as to be insulting
word.example: e.g. Many people associate the concept of psychotherapy with lying on a couch whilst an inquisitorial individual asks about your childhood.
word.etymology: from the Latin inquirere: to inquire; inquisitorial literally means '(of a trial) in which the judge has a role as inquirer'

word.name: insignia
word.meaning: a mark that characterises something
word.example: e.g. Instead of buying a ring, the film producer Matthew Vaugn presented Claudia Schiffer with a tortoise as an insignia of their engagement.
word.etymology: 1640s, from Latin insignia, neuter plural of insigne "badge, mark," from in- "in" (see in- (2)) + signum "mark" (see sign). Singular is insigne.

word.name: insouciance
word.meaning: an attitude devoid of worry
word.example: e.g. Princess Grace's fatal car crash was on a road she knew well from filming To Catch a Thief: no it was not insouciance that killed the actress but a stroke.
word.etymology: from the French insouciant: not caring, from in: not, and sociant: worrying.

word.name: insurrection
word.meaning: the act of rising up against an authority
word.example: e.g. Actor Toby Stephens has joked he will never play James Bond because casting a Bond 'with reddish hair would cause insurrection'.
word.etymology: from the Latin insurrectio, from insurgere: to rise up.

word.name: internecine
word.meaning: relating to strife within a group of people
word.example: e.g. The novelist Marcel Proust enjoyed placing starving rats in the same cage; when they tore each other to pieces, he would become sexually excited by this internecine display.
word.etymology: from the Latin inter: among, and necare: to kill

word.name: interregnum
word.meaning: the period falling between reigns by two different rulers
word.example: e.g. The gap between the Queen's death and the coronation of her successor will form an interregnum.
word.etymology: from the Latin inter: between, and regnum: reign

word.name: invective
word.meaning: abusive language
word.example: e.g. Tired of his wife's invective, War and Peace author Leo Tolstoy left her a note stating his wish to spend his 'last days alone and in silence'. He died soon after.
word.etymology: from the Latin invectivuus: abusive, from invectus, past participle of invehere: to attack with words.

word.name: inveigh against
word.meaning: to verbally attack (something)
word.example: e.g. Knowing that the public blames capitalists for the credit crunch, politicians frequently inveigh against bankers.
word.etymology: from the Latin invehi: to attack with words

word.name: invidious
word.meaning: (of a comparison) discriminating between people in an unfair fashion
word.example: e.g. A mother will rarely say which of her sons is her favourite because she knows no happiness can come from such an invidious comment.
word.etymology: c.1600, from Latin invidiosus "full of envy, envious," from invidia "envy, grudge, jealousy, ill will" (see envy). Related: Invidiously; invidiousness.

word.name: inviolable
word.meaning: never to be destroyed
word.example: e.g. The Catholic Church does not allow divorces to marry again, viewing marriage vows as inviolable.
word.etymology: from the Latin inviolabolis: invulnerable, from in: not, and violare: to do violence to

word.name: irascible
word.meaning: (or a person) growing angry easily
word.example: e.g. Composer Brahms used to shoot cats with a bow and arrow: he hated them so much that the mere sight of a feline made him irascible
word.etymology: late 14c., from Middle French irascible (12c.) and directly from Late Latin irascibilis, from Latin irasci "be angry, be in a rage," from ira "anger" (see ire).

word.name: jejune
word.meaning: too simple; OR dull
word.example: e.g. Whereas the views of most teenagers are jejune, the narrator of The Catcher in the Rye delivers mature insights that expose the hypocrisies of adults.
word.etymology: from the Latin jejunus: fasting; this sense of 'being physically undernourished' (as a result of fasting) evolved to mean 'being intellectually undernourished'

word.name: jeremiad
word.meaning: a long moan
word.example: e.g. Lord Byron was so fat he used to play cricket wearing a total of seven waistcoats in a bid to lose weight; when this failed, he embarked on a jerimiad.
word.etymology: jeremiad derives from the name of Jeremiah, who features in the Bible. Jeremiah was notorious for moaning - mainly about the destruction of Jerusalem (as described in The Lamentations of Jeremiah in the Old Testament). Today, when we use the word jeremiad, we conjure up the image of one long complaint.

word.name: journeyman
word.meaning: a worker or sportsman who is reliable but not the best
word.example: e.g. Roger Federer is famous but few people know the names of the lower-ranked journeymen of the tennis world.
word.etymology: In Middle English, 'a journey' used to mean 'a day's work' and a journeyman therefore referred to a worker who was paid for each day he worked - but whom the employer did not consider good enough to give a full-time contract to. When we use the word journeyman today, we evoke this pejorative sense of someone who is an 'also-ran'.

word.name: juju
word.meaning: a lucky charm
word.example: e.g. James Joyce was a superstitious man who used to carry around rabbit's ears and other jujus to bring himself luck.
word.etymology: from the French joujou: toy

word.name: juvenilia
word.meaning: works produced by an artist in his youth
word.example: e.g. Imagine the excitement if somebody discovered the unread juvenilia of Shakespeare
word.etymology: from the Latin juvenis: a young person

word.name: Kafkaesque
word.meaning: (of a situation) marked by menace and complexity
word.example: e.g. Britons who are put on trial abroad often find the process Kafkaesque compared to the relatively straightforward British legal system.
word.etymology: Kafkaesque refers to those unpleasant situations and ideas that are suggestive of the books of Czech novelist Franz Kafka (1883-1924). Kafka's most famous novel, The Trial, tells the story of a man arrested and prosecuted by an enigmatic authority; but he never finds out what he has done wrong. The term 'Kafkaesque' is today applied to any situation where an individual is accused of a crime but where little - if any - evidence is offered to substantiate the accusation.

word.name: ken
word.meaning: the range of what one knows
word.example: e.g. Ivan the Terrible (1530-1584) used to sew victims into bearskins, then hunt them down with hounds; such cruelty is beyond most people's ken.
word.etymology: from the German kennen: to know

word.name: lackadaisical
word.meaning: lacking in keenness
word.example: e.g. John Wayne made acting look natural because he appeared lackadaisical on screen.
word.etymology: from the archaic interjection 'lack-a-day' of a listless person which was used to convey disapproval; a phrase.

word.name: laconic
word.meaning: uttering few words
word.example: e.g. Boxer Mike Tyson never gave much away in post-fight interviews: he is a laconic man.
word.etymology: laconic originates from a place in Greece called 'Laconia' (to which the Greeks give the adjective Lakonikos). The inhabitants of Laconia (which was also known as Sparta) were notorious for not saying much; hence, when we call someone laconic today, we evoke this sense of terseness.

word.name: lacuna
word.meaning: a gap that has not been filled
word.example: e.g. After she read of a friend's death, Florence Nightingale was so affected by the resulting lacuna in her life that she cancelled her daily newspaper lest she read of any other such deaths.

word.name: lambent
word.meaning: (of light) flickering softly; (of humour) brilliant but with a light touch
word.example: e.g. 'I told you I was ill' were the words chosen by Spike Milligan for his epitaph: it was typical of him to treat his own death with such a lambent wit.
word.etymology: from the Latin lambent: licking, from lambere: to lick

word.name: lampoon
word.meaning: to hold up to public ridicule
word.example: e.g. For years, the magazine Private Eye has lampooned celebrities.
word.etymology: from the French lampoon: originally meaning 'a drinking song', later 'a lampoon', deriving from lampons: let us drink, a refrain of 17th-century songs.

word.name: lapidary
word.meaning: (or language) so elegant that it is worth engraving on stone
word.example: e.g. Ernest Hemingway's dislike of adjectives means his sentences are concise and lapidary.
word.etymology: from the Latin lapis, lapidis: a stone

word.name: lard with
word.meaning: to enliven (sentences) with a variety of expressions
word.example: e.g. Ex-French President Mitterrand was fond of larding his speeches with quotations from Balzac and other French writers of old.
word.etymology: from the Greek larinos: fat; lard with literally means 'to smear a foodstuff with lard to prevent it from dying out during storage'

word.name: leaven
word.meaning: to change (something) for the better
word.example: e.g. The director Quentin Tarantino uses humorous dialogue to leaven the violence in his films.
word.etymology: from the Latin levare: to lift

word.name: legerdemain
word.meaning: sleight of hand
word.example: e.g. for years Oscar Wilde exercised considerable legerdemain in concealing his homosexuality from the public; but eventually he was outed and jailed.
word.etymology: from the French leger de main: light of hand; legerdemain literally means 'skilful use of one's hand when performing conjuring tricks'

word.name: leonine
word.meaning: like a lion
word.example: e.g. Bjorn Borg has maintained his long yellow hair into his middle age and with it his leonine look.
word.etymology: from the Latin lea, leonis: a lion

word.name: lese-majesty
word.meaning: an attack on authority
word.example: e.g. The French revolution (1789-1799), and the use of the guillotine that accompanied it, was the ultimate act of lese-majesty.
word.etymology: from the Latin laesa majestas: injured sovereignty; lese-majesty literally means 'the insulting of a ruler'.

word.name: leviathan
word.meaning: something very large, especially a large sea creature
word.example: e.g. Billionaires often buy themselves large yachts and then hold parties on these leviathans.
word.etymology: leviathan is used in the Bible to refer to various monsters, such as the whale and the crocodile (in Job) and to the ultimate monster, the Devil (in Isaiah). Today, it continues to evoke any dangerous aquatic creature - often a whale but not always - or any large organisation or object (not necessarily a sea creature).

word.name: libertine
word.meaning: a person, especially a man, who disregards all moral codes, particularly in sexual matters
word.example: e.g. In the film Dangerous Liaisons, John Malkovich plays the ultimate libertine: an aristocrat who sexually corrupts the innocent.
word.etymology: from the Latin libertinus: freedman, from liber: free

word.name: licentious
word.meaning: unbridled in sexual matters
word.example: e.g. James Bond beds several women in each film, reflecting his licentious approach to relationships.
word.etymology: from the Latin licentia: freedom

word.name: Lilliputian
word.meaning: very small in size; OR trivial
word.example: e.g. Paris may be the capital city of France, but it seems Lilliputian when compared to the sprawling metropolis that is London.
word.etymology: The Lilliputians were people around six inches tall who inhabited the fictional island of Lilliput in Jonathan Swift's novel Gulliver's Travels (1726). In the novel, Gulliver is washed up on the island of Lilliput, and implored by the tiny Lilliputians to fight the people on a neighbouring island. The island of Lilliput was used by Swift to parody England at the time. For example, Swift talks about a conflict in Lilliput between those people who prefer to open an egg from its big end and those people who opt for the small end; this is a reference to the ongoing arguments in England between the Catholics (the 'Big-Endians') and the Protestants (the 'Little-Endians'). Today, we use the word Lilliputian to denote something that is physically tiny or a matter that is very trivial.

word.name: liminal
word.meaning: in a transitional state
word.example: e.g. As he waited for the defeated President Bush to see out his final days in office, President-elect Barack Obama found himself in a liminal state.
word.etymology: from the Latin limen, liminis: a threshold; liminal literally means 'standing on both sides of a threshold'.

word.name: limpid
word.meaning: (of liquid or of writing) crystal clear
word.example: e.g. Brigitte Bardot was an iconic sex symbol of the 1960s, renowned for her limpid blue eyes.
word.etymology: from the Latin limpidus: clear

word.name: lingua franca
word.meaning: a language that is taken on as a common language between speakers whose mother tongues are different
word.example: e.g. English people on holiday in France use 'franglais' to communicate with the locals: basic exchanges can be effected using this lingua franca.
word.etymology: from the Italian, lingua franca: Frankish tongue

word.name: litotes
word.meaning: ironic understatement in which a sentiment is expressed by negating its contrary proposition
word.example: e.g. I deduced from the English teacher's use of the litotes: 'I am not unfamiliar with the works of Dickens', that he was an expert on the novelist.
word.etymology: from the Greek liotes, from litos: plain, meagre

word.name: lodestar
word.meaning: a person or thing that serves as a guiding force
word.example: e.g. Barack Obama cites Martin Luther King so often that it is clear King is a lodestar for him.
word.etymology: from the Middle English lodesterre, from lode: way, and steree: star; lodestar literally means 'a star that is used to guide the course of a ship'.

word.name: logorrheic
word.meaning: uncontrollably talkative
word.example: e.g. Freud said of the Irish: "This is one race of people whom psychoanalysis is of no use whatsoever." Presumably because the Irish are so logorrheic that it is hard to know which bits coming out of their mouths are important.

word.name: lore
word.meaning: a body of knowledge on a topic, that has typically been passed from person to person via the oral tradition
word.example: e.g. When writing the Bond novel Devil May Care, Sebastian Faulks consulted Ian Fleming's family on matters of Bond lore.
word.etymology: from the Old English lar: instruction, of Germanic origin, related to the German Lehre: learning.

word.name: Luddite
word.meaning: a person who is against new technology
word.example: e.g. Some people over the age of 70 are Luddites who do not know how to suurf the Internet.
word.etymology: Luddite derives from the name of Ned Lud, a member of a 19th-century group of English cotton mill workers who destroyed machinery that was threatening to take over their jobs. Today, when we call someone a Luddite, we are referring to someone who opposes new technology of any kind.

word.name: ludic
word.meaning: playful
word.example: e.g. Playwright Arthur Miller praised his ex-wife Marilyn Monroe for her sense of fun, and noted that most adults lacked this ludic quality.
word.etymology: from the Latin ludere: to play

word.name: Machiavellian
word.meaning: wily and unscrupulous in furthering one's own career
word.example: e.g. The public regards politicians as Machiavellian types
word.etymology: Machiavellian originates from the name of Machiavelli, a Renaissance Italian statesman. Machiavelli's book The Prince (1532) advises rulers that unethical methods are necessary if power is to be seized and effectively wielded. Today, we continue to describe someone as Machiavellian if they stab rivals in the back, or mistreat people in other ways in the pursuit of power.

word.name: magisterial
word.meaning: authoritative
word.example: e.g. Steven Spielberg's self-confidence means he exudes a magisterial air on set.
word.etymology: from the Latin magister: master

word.name: malapropism
word.meaning: mistakenly using one word in the place of another (often with an unintentionally comic effect)
word.example: e.g. I decided to tell my friends about my flamenco dancing lessons but it came out wrong and I ended up saying: 'I can dance a flamingo now', they laughed at my malapropism.
word.etymology: malapropism derives from the name of the character Mrs Malaprop in Richard Sheridan's play The Rivals (1775). Mys Malaprop has the habit of getting words confused, which is a source of humour in the play. Her name was chosen because of the link to the French phrase mal a propos, which means 'ill-suited' and describes perfectly the jumbled order of her words. Today, when we say that someone has committed a malapropism, we mean they are guilty of a similar linguistic slip-up.

word.name: malfeasance
word.meaning: malpractice, especially by a public official
word.example: e.g. The MP's expenses' scandal revealed that politicians had been using tyaqxpayers' money to pay a variety of items for personal use: this malfeasance caused a public outcry.
word.etymology: from the Old French mal: evil, and faisance: activity

word.name: malinger
word.meaning: to pretend to be ill to avoid work
word.example: e.g. Every year the government loses millions of pounds owing to workers pretending to be sick; as taxpayers, we are all victims of this malingering.
word.etymology: from the Old French mal: wrongly, and haingre: weak

word.name: mandarin
word.meaning: a powerful government worker
word.example: e.g. In the UK, the head of MI6 is one of the most powerful mandarins
word.etymology: ultimately deriving from the Sanskrit mantri: a counsellor; a mandarin literally refers to a bureaucrat in imperial Chine (AD 900-1800).

word.name: Manichaean
word.meaning: relating to a view that divides the world very starkly into good and evil
word.example: e.g. George Bush spoke about certain countries forming an 'axis of evil': this implies he sees the world in Manichaean terms, with the USA being 'good', and these other mentioned countries as being 'evil'.
word.etymology: Manichaean derives from 'Manichaeism', a 3rd-century religion that was one of the most popular in the world at the time. This religion was based on the teachings of the Iranian prophet Mani who was privy to divine truths from a spirit who visited him. Manichaeism is distinguished by its viewing the world as a clear-cut struggle between good (or 'spiritually'); and evil (or 'materialism'); today, when we call someone Manichaean, we mean they see the world as being divided very clearly between good and evil.

word.name: manque
word.meaning: referring to someone who missed out on a particular role
word.example: e.g. US senator Ted Kennedy never achieved his political potential because allegations of drinking and womanising dogged him throughout his life: he was the President manque
word.etymology: from the French manquer: to miss

word.name: marionette
word.meaning: a puppet controlled from above by strings attached to it
word.example: e.g. The SS was a major Nazi organisation composed of one million of Hitler's marionettes
word.etymology: from the French marionette: little Mary, the diminutive form of Marion, which is itself the diminutive of Marie

word.name: marmoreal
word.meaning: like marble
word.example: e.g. To those who found actress Grace Kelly marmoreal, Alfred Hitchcock said of his leading lady that she had 'fire under the ice'.
word.etymology: from the Latin marmor: marble

word.name: martinet
word.meaning: a strict taskmaster
word.example: e.g. 'Fat farms' are populated by obese people who are whipped into shape by martinets.
word.etymology: martinet derives from the name of the 17th-century Frenchman Jean Martinet, a highly-ordered man who trained soldiers. Tired of having to deal with fickle mercenaries, Martinet devised a rigorous programme to turn members of the public into effective military servicemen. It is a cruel irony that this paragon of discipline was killed by 'friendly fire': a fatal form of ill-discipline. Today, the word martinet refers to any disciplinarian.

word.name: maunder on
word.meaning: to talk in a meandering fashion; OR to move or act as if time is of no concern
word.example: e.g. In his satirical sketches of political figures, Rory Bremner contorts his face to better depict his victims as he maunders on in their tone of voice.
word.etymology: from the Old English maund: to beg, deriving from the French mendier: to beg.

word.name: maw
word.meaning: the throat of a ravenous animal
word.example: e.g. The Hound of the Baskervilles is a story about a giant dog suspected of killing people using its fearsome maw.
word.etymology: from the German Magen: stomach

word.name: mawkish
word.meaning: sentimental in a nausea-inducing way
word.example: e.g. The final scene of a 'rom com' typically involves a girl running into the arms of a boy or some other equally mawkish scene.
word.etymology: from the Old English mawke: maggot; mawkish originally meant 'to be disgusted', as if by a putrid meat.

word.name: mellifluous
word.meaning: (of a voice) honey-coated
word.example: e.g. The advent of sound meant Clark Gable's career took off overnight because there was suddenly huge demand for his mellifluous voice.
word.etymology: from the Latin mellifluus, from mel: honey, and fluere: to flow

word.name: menagerie
word.meaning: a diverse mixture of people or animals
word.example: e.g. Each year the cast of Celebrity Big Brother is made up of a variety of people in the public eye, such as TV stars and glamour models: a veritable menagerie of individuals.
word.etymology: A menagerie was a 16th-century French term used to describe a collection of exotic animals kept in captivity; the French word menagerie is derived from the word menage, meaning 'a household'. A menagerie was often retained by a royal court, no so much as to study the animal world but rather to signify the opulence of the menagerie's owner (as exotic animals were very expensive to purchase). Today, menagerie refers to any diverse collection of things or people.

word.name: mercurial
word.meaning: very moody
word.example: e.g. Idi Amin (1925-2003), the despotic ruler of Uganda for many years, was a mercurial man who had people executed on a whim.
word.etymology: mercurial derives from the Latin word mercurialis, which meant 'relating to the god Mercury'. The god Mercury would fly quickly from one place to another and back again - it is this erraticism (albeit of a mental, rather than a physical, kind) that we evoke when we call someone mercurial today.

word.name: meretricious
word.meaning: alluring but vulgar
word.example: e.g. A woman who obviously had breast augmentation surgery holds a meretricious appeal for some men.
word.etymology: from the Latin meretrix, meretricis: a prostitute; meretricious literally means 'like a prostitute'.

word.name: metonym
word.meaning: a word used instead of another word with which it is closely linked
word.example: e.g. Newspapers are produced using a printing press; hence the term 'the press' has become a metonym to describe all newspapers collectively.
word.etymology: from the Greek metanomasia: change of name

word.name: miasma
word.meaning: an atmosphere that has been polluted
word.example: e.g. during the Second World War, Jews in Germany lived their lives in a miasma of fear and suspicion.
word.etymology: from the Greek miama: a stain (especially due to a murder)

word.name: microcosm
word.meaning: a situation that reflects on a smaller scale the qualities of a larger situation
word.example: e.g. Some saw England's defeat of Germany in the 1966 Football World Cup as a microcosm of England's defeat of Germany in World War II.

word.name: mimesis
word.meaning: the rendering of the real world in art
word.example: e.g. Shakespeare's play Henry V is a mimesis of Britain's victory over the French at Agincourt.
word.etymology: from the Greek mimeistai: to imitate

word.name: misnomer
word.meaning: a name that is wrong
word.example: e.g. A horseshoe crab looks more like a stingray than a crab: so the term 'horseshow crab' is a misnomer.
word.etymology: from the old French mesnommer: to misname, from mes: wrongly, and nommer: to name

word.name: monoglot
word.meaning: speaking one language only
word.example: e.g. As English is spoken the world over, most English people get away with being monoglot
word.etymology: from the Greek monos: single, and glotta: tongue

word.name: monolithic
word.meaning: (of an organisation or a building) very large and without quirks
word.example: e.g. The Chinese Communist Party plays down the importance of any one individual, reflecting its monolithic nature
word.etymology: from the Greek monos: single, and lithos: stone; monolithic literally means 'formed of a single large block of stone'

word.name: moratorium
word.meaning: a temporary ban of an activity
word.example: e.g. With the world's supply of fish on the wane, governments agreed a moratorium on code fishing.
word.etymology: from the Latin moratorius: delaying

word.name: mordant
word.meaning: (of humour) biting
word.example: e.g. The comments directed by Simon Cowell towards aspirant singers on his TV show The X Factor are full of mordant humour
word.etymology: from the French mordre: to bite

word.name: multifarious
word.meaning: having many parts
word.example: e.g. Catholicism and Anglicanism are two of the multifarious branches of the Christian faith.
word.etymology: from the Latin multifarious: manifold, combined with the Greek farius: showing

word.name: munificent
word.meaning: particularly generous
word.example: e.g. Robert Redford used his salary from Butch Cassidy and the Sundance Kid to set up the Sundance Film Festival for independent films: a munificent gesture.
word.etymology: from the Latin munificus: bountiful

word.name: myopic
word.meaning: having no foresight
word.example: e.g. Mike Tyson disconcerted Evander Holyfield by taking a bite out of his ear during their boxing fight; later, though, Tyson was disqualified, proving this was a myopic tactic.
word.etymology: "short-sighted," 1800, from myopia + -ic. Figurative use from 1891. Related: Myopical (1748); myopically.

word.name: nativism
word.meaning: the policy of favouring the interests of native-born inhabitants above those of immigrants
word.example: e.g. There is a campaign on Facebook called 'People United Against Nativism' whose slogan is: 'nativism is so 19th century'
word.etymology: deriving from the English word, native

word.name: nebulous/amorphous
word.meaning: (of a shape) unclear
word.example: e.g. Jamie Oliver has never been filmed cooking in the nude, so the reasons for his being called The Naked Chef are nebulous/amorphous
word.etymology: nebulous derives from the Latin nebula: a cloud (nebulous literally means 'in the form of a cloud'); amorphous derives from the Greek amorphous: shapeless, from a: without, and morphe: form

word.name: nemesis
word.meaning: the punishment for excessive pride (see also hubris)
word.example: e.g. Bernard Madoff showed hubris in believing he could deceive so many investors forever; nemesis came when his fraud was discovered he was imprisoned for life
word.etymology: from the Greek nemesis: retribution

word.name: neologism
word.meaning: a newly invented word or expression
word.example: e.g. The advent of the Internet led to neologisms such as 'to surf the net' which are now commonly used
word.etymology: from the Greek neos: new, and logos: word

word.name: netherworld
word.meaning: the part of society involved in crime
word.example: e.g. Newspapers often report murders and other crimes; it seems that every type of netherworld is of interest to journalists
word.etymology: from the Old English nether: lower, and world; netherworld literally means: 'the underworld of the dead'

word.name: nexus
word.meaning: a connection binding together two or more things
word.example: e.g. Barack Obama has declared his intention to break the nexus between 'Big Oil' and politics
word.etymology: from the Latin nex: bound, from nectere: to bind

word.name: nimbus
word.meaning: a large rain cloud
word.example: e.g. I rushed home to grab an umbrella after I saw the nimbuses overhead
word.etymology: from the Latin nimbus: cloud

word.name: noblesse oblige
word.meaning: the responsibility of privileged people to show generosity to those less privileged
word.example: e.g. Angelina Jolie does much charity work for landmine victims: she is a celebrity who exercises noblesse oblige
word.etymology: In his novel Le Lys dans la vallee (which translates as The Lily of the Valley), the 19th century French novelist Balzac summarises his advice to a rich young man by the two words: 'noblesse oblige!'. This phrase - which literally means 'nobility creates obligations' - is cited today as a reminder that, with great wealth comes great responsibility: the rich have a duty to help the poor. Today, we use the phrase noblesse oblige to remind someone who has enjoyed success that they should help others who have fared less well.

word.name: nomenclature
word.meaning: the act of choosing names for things; OR the collection of names thus chosen
word.example: e.g. To describe female acting professionals, the term 'actors' is now preferred to the original nomenclature of 'actresses'.
word.etymology: from the Latin nomenclatura, from nomen: name, and clatura: calling (from calare: to call)

word.name: normative
word.meaning: establishing a rule or behaviour
word.example: e.g. Marriage has a normative effect on society because it ensures communities are composed on tight-knit groups made up of parents and offspring.
word.etymology: from the Latin norma: a rule

word.name: nostrum
word.meaning: a favourite but usually hopeless schema for effecting social improvement
word.example: e.g. To stem rising numbers of single parent families and encourage more family units, John Major announced his nostrum: the Back to Basics campaign
word.etymology: from the Latin nostrum: 'our own make' - a term used in ancient times by quacks claiming special virtue for their own make of wares; a nostrum literally means 'an ineffective medicine prepared by an unqualified person'.

word.name: numinous
word.meaning: relating to the spiritual and the mysterious
word.example: e.g. In the secular 21st century, art and literature have for many replaced religion as a means of accessing the numinous.
word.etymology: from the Latin number, numis: divine power

word.name: obfuscate
word.meaning: to bewilder
word.example: e.g. Literary novels sometimes fall to sell well because the average reader finds the complicated structure of such novels frequently obfuscates the story (if indeed there is one).
word.etymology: from the Latin obfuscare: to darken; obfuscate literally means 'to make obscure'

word.name: oblique
word.meaning: not direct in dealing with a point
word.example: e.g. Jeremy Paxman once asked Michael Howard the same question 12 times in a row because he was finding the politician's responses so oblique.
word.etymology: from the Latin obliquus: slanted; oblique literally means 'neither parallel nor at a right angle to a specified line'

word.name: obscurantist
word.meaning: describes someone who casts a veil over the facts
word.example: e.g. After a long period of being obscurantist on their interrogation methods, the CIA finally admitted it had used 'water-boarding' on terrorist suspects.
word.etymology: from the Latin obscurare: to make dark

word.name: obtuse
word.meaning: annoyingly slow to grasp (something)
word.example: e.g. Doctors must not allow themselves to be overly affected by human suffering: perhaps this is why they can appear obtuse to some patients.
word.etymology: from the Latin obtusus, past participle of obtundere: to beat against.

word.name: oleaginous
word.meaning: obsequious
word.example: e.g. Tony Blair's friends describe him as charming, while his enemies call him oleaginous/unctuous.
word.etymology: oleaginous derives from oleaginus: of the olive tree, from oleum: oil (oleaginous literally means 'oily'); untuous derives from the Latin unguere: to annoint

word.name: olfactory
word.meaning: relating to the sense of smell
word.example: e.g. To smell a bunch of flowers is an olfactory treat
word.etymology: from the Latin olfacere: to smell

word.name: opaque
word.meaning: hard to make out
word.example: e.g. Isaac Newton used to deliver lecture after lecture to empty rooms: jis pupils had all stopped turning up because they found his talks to opaque
word.etymology: from the Latin opacus: darkened

word.name: opprobrium
word.meaning: bitter criticism
word.example: e.g. Homophobia attracts opprobrium in the West
word.etymology: from the Latin opprobrium: reproach, from ob: against, and probum: disgraceful act

word.name: ordure
word.meaning: something horrid
word.example: e.g. Agatha Christie hated her fictional creation Hercule Poirot, calling him 'an egocentric creep' and referring to him as though he were ordure.
word.etymology: from the Latin horridus: horrid; ordure literally means 'excrement'

word.name: ornery
word.meaning: ill-tempered
word.example: e.g. Despite having a painful back which necessitated frequent operations, John F Kennedy never appeared ornery in public.
word.etymology: ornery is a 19th-century dialectical variant of 'ordinary'

word.name: orotund
word.meaning: (of a voice) full; OR (of writing) pompous
word.example: e.g. Actor Laurence Olivier's voice used to fill any theatre: it was one of the most orotund in the business
word.etymology: from the Latin ore rotundo: with rounded mouth

word.name: Orwellian
word.meaning: (of an authority) contrary to the welfare of a free society - as described by the novelist George Orwell
word.example: e.g. Belgian citizens are required to carry a national ID card at all times - an imposition which some describe as Orwellian
word.etymology: Orwellian means reminiscent of the works of George Orwell (1903-1950), particularly his novel Nineteen Eighty Four. In Nineteen Eighty Four, a civil servant called Winston Smith has the job of falsifying records to make it appear the government is always right. The term Orwellian is today used to describe any attempt by government to control individuals by similarly-doctored propaganda or by any other means, such as surveillance.

word.name: outre
word.meaning: beyond the pale
word.example: e.g. Outre comments by Jonathan Ross led to his suspension without pay by the BBC for 12 weeks in 2008.
word.etymology: from the French outre: exceeded, from the past participle of outrer: to exceed

word.name: oxymoron
word.meaning: a phrase involving contradictory terms placed side by side to produce an amusing result
word.example: e.g. Robin Hood stole from the rich but gave to the poor: you could call him 'an honest rogue' if you like that oxymoron
word.etymology: from the Greek oxumoros: pointedly foolish, from oxus: sharp, and moros: foolish

word.name: palimpest
word.meaning: something that displays its past (as well as its present)
word.example: e.g. The police shone infrared lights inside Fred West's home, revealing palimpests of bloodstains that the serial killer had sought to wash away
word.etymology: palimpest literally refers to an ancient Roman manuscript on which the original writing had been rubbed away to make room for later writing (as was the Roman custom); hence the Greek etymology, palin 'again', and psestos: 'scraped' - so palimpest literally means 'scraped (clean and used) again'. However the original writing was not lost forever; with the passing of time, the faint outlines of the earlier writing would reappear with sufficient clarity for scholars to read it. Today, we use palimpest to describe an object that displays its past (as well as its present) - for example, our brain is the ultimate palimpest, retaining so much information about our past while also accounting for our present behaviour.

word.name: palliative
word.meaning: relieving a problem without curing it
word.example: e.g. It is said that Queen Victoria used marijuana to relieve menstrual pain: the drug was her palliative of choice
word.etymology: from the Latin palliatus: cloaked

word.name: panache
word.meaning: a flamboyant conviction in one's own sense of style
word.example: e.g. The quality that makes Roger Federer so easy to watch as a tennis player is not his fitness or serve but his overall panache.
word.etymology: from the French panache, itself derived from the Italian pennachio: a plume of feathers

word.name: Panglossian
word.meaning: a person who is optimistic whatever happens
word.example: e.g. The press depicted Gordon Brown as Panglossian in taking so long to acknowledge the UK was in the grip of a credit crunch.
word.etymology: Pangloss is a character in the novel Candide by Voltaire (1694-1778). He is a tutor charged with educating the young Candide, who lives in beautiful surrounds; Pangloss is an optimistic teacher whose mantra is as follows: 'all is for the best in the best possible of worlds'. Candide eventually leaves his pampered existence and witnesses such suffering in the world that he abandons Pangloss's rosy world view in favour of his own pragmatic philosophy, which is: 'all you can do is tend your own garden'. Today, we continue to describe anyone who is excessively optimistic as Panglossian.

word.name: panoply
word.meaning: an admirable collection of things
word.example: e.g. Actress Marlene Dietrich once wore a gown containing feathers from 300 swans: a panoply of plumage
word.etymology: from the Latin panoplia: full armour, from the Greek panoplia: all, and hopla: arms

word.name: pantheon
word.meaning: a group of illustrious people
word.example: e.g. Alfred Hitchcock never received an Oscar despite his undisputed place amongst the pantheon of film directors.
word.etymology: pantheon literally meant in ancient Greece 'a temple of all gods', deriving from the Greek word pan: all, and theos: god. Indeed the most famous such structure retains the word in its name: the Pantheon of Rome (built in 27BC). Since the 16th century the word pantheon has come to mean 'an exalted set of people'.

word.name: paradigm
word.meaning: a model
word.example: e.g. Audrey Hepburn was the paradigm of success at a young age, winning an Oscar for her very first film, Roman Holiday.
word.etymology: from the Greek paradeigma: a model

word.name: paragon
word.meaning: a person or thing viewed as a benchmark for others
word.example: e.g. Christiano Ronaldo is one of the world's most expensive players because he is a paragon of footballing excellence.
word.etymology: paragon derives from the Italian word paragone, meaning 'a touchstone to test gold'. The touchstone in question was black quartz (a semi-precious mineral), which was used for testing the quality of gold alloys by rubbing them on it and then comparing the streak left behind by the gold alloy with a streak left by pure gold (which leaves a clear yellow line behind). Gradually paragon assumed its current figurative usage, referring today to a model of excellence by which other people or things must be judged. (See also touchstone, which has a near-identical meaning).

word.name: parenthetical
word.meaning: within (or as if within) a parenthesis, which is an explanatory phrase enclosed by curved brackets
word.example: e.g. Conversations with Fidel Castro are reported to last for hours; presumably this is because the Cuban leader indulges in parenthetical asides when he talks.
word.etymology: from the Greek parentithenai: to put in beside

word.name: par excellence
word.meaning: superior to others of the same kind
word.example: e.g. American financier Warren Buffett has won a reputation for being an investor par excellence
word.etymology: from the French par excellence: by excellence

word.name: parlay (something) into (something more valuable)
word.meaning: to convert (something) into (something more valuable)
word.example: e.g. The young Sir James Goldsmith joined his brother in a pharmaceutical venture; from this he amassed a tidy sum which he went on to parlay into billions.
word.etymology: from the Latin par: equal

word.name: parlous
word.meaning: fraught with danger
word.example: e.g. Gangster Al Capone's health was always in a parlous state due to his refusal to receive injections.
word.etymology: parlous is a Middle English contraction of 'perilous'

word.name: parochial
word.meaning: having a narrow world-view
word.example: e.g. The British regard Americans as having a parochial world-view because less than one third of Americans have passports.
word.etymology: from the Greek paroikos: a neighbour

word.name: paroxysm
word.meaning: a sudden expression of an emotion; OR a sudden bout of a disease
word.example: e.g After his wife died in a plane crash, actor Clark Gable turned to drink in a paroxysm of grief.
word.etymology: from the Greek paroxusmos: a severe fit of a disease, deriving from para: (intensifying prefix) and oxunein: to sharpen

word.name: parse
word.meaning: to examine (something) closely, especially by breaking it up into parts
word.example: e.g. Scientists can easily parse the behaviour of chimpanzees into the conventional categories of human comportment.
word.etymology: from the Latin pars: part

word.name: parsimonious
word.meaning: frugal
word.example: e.g. Most of the world's religions advise the faithful to lead a parsimonious life
word.etymology: from the Latin parsimonia: frugality

word.name: paternalist
word.meaning: relating to the practice by rulers of limiting the freedom of those being ruled (purportedly for the good of the latter)
word.example: e.g. After Saddam Hussain's removal, the US waited for such a long time before allowing democratic elections in Iraq that accusations of paternalist behaviour abounded.
word.etymology: from the Latin pater: father

word.name: pathetic fallacy
word.meaning: the attribution in artistic works of human feelings to non-human things
word.example: e.g. Novelists are fond of using pathetic fallacy; an example can be found in the use of the expression 'the sky is weeping' instead of the more conventional 'it is raining'
word.etymology: pathetic fallacy is composed of the Greek word pathos, meaning 'the quality that arouses pity', and the Latin word fallere: to deceive. As a pathetic fallacy refers to depicting non-human things in a human light (which is a popular activity of artists), it is no surprise that it was an art critic. John Ruskin, who coined the term, noting in his book Modern Painters (1856) that the pathetic fallacy had as its aim 'to signify any description of inanimate natural objects that ascribes to them human capabilities...'. An everyday example of a pathetic fallacy is when someone looks up and says of the rain falling from above: 'the sky is weeping'.

word.name: pathological
word.meaning: caused by a disease
word.example: e.g. Sportsmen who reach world number one are usually pathologically competitive.
word.etymology: from the Greek pathos: suffering, disease, and logos: word

word.name: patina
word.meaning: a surface that has changed due to age
word.example: e.g. The face of a 90 year old is etched with a patina of fine lines and wrinkles
word.etymology: from the Latin patina: a shallow dish (which is an example of a piece of crockery prone to incrustations caused by the passing of time)

word.name: patrician
word.meaning: belonging to an illustrious and wealthy family
word.example: e.g. Daniella Steel has no need for the riches from her 580m book sales for she was born into a patrician family.
word.etymology: from the Latin patricius: having a noble father

word.name: Pavlovian
word.meaning: relating to a response that, over time, can be elicited by one stimulus alone (when at first two stimuli were needed)
word.example: e.g. When I see my wife putting on her apron, I start salivating - before she has even touched any food - due to a Pavlovian response to that apron of hers
word.etymology: Pavlovian is an expression deriving from the work of Ivan Pavlov (1849-1936), a Russian scientist who won the Nobel Prize. Pavlov noted that dogs salivate when food is presented to them; far more significantly, he also noticed that - if you ring a bell seconds before presenting the food - eventually the bell alone will be enough to produce the salivation (even if no food is ever presented). Thus Pavlov concluded that some responses by an animal are based on that animal's previous experiences (and are not just based on an animal's reflexes). Today, we use the word Pavlovian to describe any response within us that we can only explain owing to a past experience coming to the fore (rather than owing to our reaction to a present stimulus outside of ourselves).

word.name: pellucid
word.meaning: (of a concept) easily grasped
word.example: e.g. Ernest Hemingway wrote such simple sentences that his novels are considered amongst the most pellucid in the English language.
word.etymology: from the Latin perlucere: to shine through, from per: through, and lucere: to shine

word.name: penitential
word.meaning: repentant
word.example: e.g. Victims of fraudster Bernard Madoff were angry that he didn't appear more penitential in court
word.etymology: from the Latin paenitentia: repentance

word.name: penurious
word.meaning: very poor
word.example: e.g. There are many charities set up in order to help penurious families
word.etymology: from the Latin penuria: need

word.name: perdition
word.meaning: hell
word.example: e.g. Many people who start off by abusing soft drugs like marijuana end up in the perdition of heroin addiction.
word.etymology: (in Christian teaching) from the Latin perditio: ruin; perdition literally means 'utter rain'

word.name: peremptory
word.meaning: (of a person's manner) insisting on total subservience
word.example: e.g. Elvis Presley once insisted on flying 500 miles in his jet to collect a peanut butter sandwich; his staff complied, afraid to refuse his peremptory request
word.etymology: from the Latin peremptorius: decisive, from perimere: to take away (from per: completely, and emere: to procure)

word.name: perfunctory
word.meaning: (of an action) done carelessly, as a matter of routine
word.example: e.g. Breakfast at Tiffany's author Truman Capote hated writing so postponed it by sharpening pencils for hours; he found this perfunctory action soothing.
word.etymology: from the Latin perfunctorious: careless

word.name: peripatetic
word.meaning: travelling around from place to place
word.example: e.g. Richard Branson is a peripatetic man who seems as likely to be in a hot air balloon halfway across the Atlantic as he is to be in London.
word.etymology: from the Greek peripatetikos: walking about, from the verb peripatein: to walk about

word.name: peroration
word.meaning: the final part of a speech (that is intended to inspire enthusiasm in the audience)
word.example: e.g. David Cameron's speeches often culminate in a stirring peroration
word.etymology: from the Latin perorare: to speak at length, from per: through, and orare: to speak

word.name: perspicacious
word.meaning: having a clear insight into things
word.example: e.g. Leonardo da Vinci was a perspicacious individual who was not just a painter but also the designer of several flying machines.
word.etymology: from the Latin perspicare: to see clearly, from per: through, and specere: to look

word.name: phalanx
word.meaning: a group of similar-looking people or things
word.example: e.g. When Arthur Conan Doyle killed off Sherlock Holmes in his short story The Final Problem, a phalanx of grief-stricken fans wearing black armbands protested outside his home.
word.etymology: phalanx is an ancient Greek word used to describe a group of soldiers who formed a defensive unit by packing themselves tightly together, overlapping their shields and extending their spears. Today, we continue to use this word to describe any group of people who look the same and stay close together - such as photographers awaiting a celebrity at a film première, or bodyguards surrounding a president. This plural of this word is phalanxes. Note though that there is an alternative plural, which is phalanges - and this has a different meaning, which is 'bones of the finger or toe': e.g. If a footballer fractures his phalanges, he is out of action for weeks.

word.name: phantasmagorical
word.meaning: relating to a sequence of surreal images as if from a dream
word.example: e.g. Lothario Errol Flynn observed that women would watch his films, create a phantasmagorical image of him, and then try a 'direct confrontation' with him.
word.etymology: from the French fantasme: phantasm

word.name: pharisaic
word.meaning: self-righteous and punctilious
word.example: e.g. Politicians who denounce adultery while themselves having affairs are pharisaic.
word.etymology: The word pharisaic derives from the Pharisees, an ancient Jewish sect notorious for their strictness and sense of superiority. In the New Testament, the Pharisees are presented as rule-followers, in contrast to Jesus who is concerned only with expressing God's love. For example, the Pharisees ostracise sinners, whereas Jesus actively seeks them out. Today, we use the word pharisaic to refer to anyone who displays self-righteousness in their obsession with following the rules.

word.name: phlegmatic
word.meaning: (of a person) having a disposition that cannot be perturbed
word.example: e.g. The Dalai Lama has a permanent smile which gives him a phlegmatic air.
word.etymology: Nowadays, phlegm is used to mean 'mucus discharged from the mouth'. However, the ancient Greeks used the word differently: for them, phlegm was one of four body fluids that account for our mood (the Greek word was phlegma, meaning 'an inflammation', reflecting the fact that phlegm was also supposed to be the cause of many diseases). Phlegm was believed to be associated with a calm, near apathetic, temperament. This sense persists in the meaning of the word phlegmatic today, which we use to describe someone who does not get rattled easily.

word.name: physiognomy
word.meaning: a person's facial features, especially when regarded as reflecting that person's character
word.example: e.g. Research shows aggressive people tend to have particularly wide faces (due to high testosterone levels): this is proof of the value of physiognomy.
word.etymology: from the Greek phusiognomonia: judging of a man's nature (by his features), based on physio: nature, and gnomon: a judge.

word.name: picaresque
word.meaning: relating to an episodic style of fiction dealing with the adventures of a dishonest but likeable hero
word.example: e.g. The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn by Mark Twain can be described as a picaresque novel because it covers the life of a roguish hero of lowly social status who lives by his wits; The White Tiger by Aravind Adiga is a modern-day example.
word.etymology: from the Spanish, picaro: rogue

word.name: plangent
word.meaning: (of a sound) like a lament
word.example: e.g. One billion people worldwide watched Michael Jackson's funeral, at which Stevie Wonder sung in plangent tones.
word.etymology: from the Latin plangere: to lament

word.name: pluralistic
word.meaning: relating to a system in which two or more groups live side by side
word.example: e.g. Muslims live alongside Christians in Britain - proof that we live in a pluralistic society.
word.etymology: from the Latin plus, plur: more

word.name: plutocrat
word.meaning: a person whose power is due to their wealth
word.example: e.g. The Prime Minister of Italy, Silvio Berlusconi, is also a billionaire who controls several TV channels: hence his being labelled a plutocrat by journalists.
word.etymology: from the Greek ploutos: wealth, and kratos: rule

word.name: poleaxed
word.meaning: to have received a huge shock
word.example: e.g. As a child, horror writer Stephen King witnessed a friend being run over by a train: the experience left him poleaxed.
word.etymology: deriving from the word poleaxe: a short-handled axe with a spike at the back; poleaxed literally means 'as if struck by a poleaxe'.

word.name: polemic
word.meaning: a strong verbal assault on someone or something
word.example: e.g. After he was convicted of the rape of Desires Washington, Miss Black Rhode Island, the press launched a polemic against Mike Tyson.
word.etymology: from the Greek polemos: war

word.name: Pollyanna
word.meaning: a person who is overly optimistic
word.example: e.g. Judy Garland got divorced from no less than four husbands but still decided to marry a fifth time: this undented optimism proves she was a Pollyanna.
word.etymology: Pollyanna originates from the name of the main character in Eleanor H. Porter's best-selling novel, Pollyanna, which was published in 1913. In the novel, Pollyanna, an orphan, goes to live with her austere aunt in a New England town in America. Pollyanna is an optimistic type who enjoys playing a game her father taught her, which involves trying to spot a good side to everything. Eventually her optimism proves infectious, transforming the town into a happy place. Today, we continue to describe anyone with such a relentlessly optimistic attitude as being a Pollyanna.

word.name: polyglot
word.meaning: knowing many languages
word.example: e.g. Rowan Williams, the Archbishop of Canterbury, talks with ease to the leaders of other world faiths because he is a polyglot.
word.etymology: from the Greek polu: many, and glotta: tongue

word.name: polymath
word.meaning: a person who has much knowledge
word.example: e.g. Leonardo da Vinci was not only a consummate painter, but he was also an inventor who designed military machines such as rapid-firing cannons: he was a true polymath
word.etymology: from the Greek polumathes: having learned much, from polu: much (the stem of manthanein to learn)

word.name: polyphonic
word.meaning: producing many sounds at the same time
word.example: e.g. At the age of two, Mozart paid a visit to a farm and, from amidst the polyphonic backdrop, identified a pig's grunt as being in G-sharp.
word.etymology: from the Greek poluphonos, from polu: many, and phone: voice

word.name: popinjay
word.meaning: a vain person
word.example: e.g. With his foppish outfits and tousled hair, Oscar Wilde was a clear example of a popinjay.
word.etymology: from the old French papegai: a parrot

word.name: porcine
word.meaning: like a pig
word.example: e.g. Dr Robert Atkins invented a low carbohydrate diet to rid himself of his own porcine appearance
word.etymology: from the Latin porcinus: a pig

word.name: portentous
word.meaning: relating to a warning that something bad is set to occur
word.example: e.g. The chief executive addressed his staff in a portentous tone, not realising that most of them were uninterested in his message and in fact daydreaming.
word.etymology: from the Latin: an omen; portentous literally means 'constituting a portent or omen'

word.name: potico
word.meaning: a portico consisting of a roof supported by columns spaced out at regular intervals
word.example: e.g. The Royal Opera House in London has a façade consisting of a giant portico.
word.etymology: from the Latin porticus: porch

word.name: portmanteau word
word.meaning: a word that has been created by blending the sounds and meanings from two or more words
word.example: e.g. Brunch is a portmanteau word coined from combining the words breakfast and lunch
word.etymology: from the French poter; to carry, and manteau: coat; portmanteau literally means 'a large suitcase that opens into two hinged halves'

word.name: potentate
word.meaning: a ruler, especially one who takes no account of other people's desire
word.example: e.g. The cringe-inducing character played by Ricky Gervais in the TV show The Office is a potentate who is blind to his own flaws.
word.etymology: from the Latin potens: powerful

word.name: prehensile
word.meaning: (of a person or animal) capable of grasping
word.example: e.g. Many bank directors responsible for the credit crunch continue to hang on to their seats with what George Orwell called 'prehensile bottoms'
word.etymology: from the Latin prehendere: to grasp

word.name: prelapsarian
word.meaning: in a pure and unspoiled state
word.example: e.g. Bankers often fondly remember their bonuses during prelapsarian years leading up to the Lehman Brothers' collapse.
word.etymology: prelapsarian derives from the Latin word lapsus and literally means 'before (pre) the Fall (lapsus)', referring to the passage in Genesis about the fall of humankind into a state of sin owing to Adam and Eve disobeying God by eating the apple in the Garden of Eden. Today, we use the word prelapsarian to evoke that period of our lives when a state of unspoiled innocence prevailed.

word.name: presage
word.meaning: (of an event) to be an indication that another event will happen
word.example: e.g. Frank Bruno's bizarre behaviour presaged his being diagnosed with bipolar disorder.
word.etymology: from the Latin praesagire: to forebode, from prae: before, and sagire: to perceive keenly

word.name: prestidigitation
word.meaning: magic tricks involving sleight of hand
word.example: e.g. In his TV shows, Derren Brown demonstrates acts of prestidigitation.
word.etymology: from the French preste: nimble, and the Latin digitus: finger

word.name: preternatural
word.meaning: beyond what is natural
word.example: e.g. Simon Cowell, inventor of The X Factor, has a preternatural ability to provide the public with what it wants.
word.etymology: from the Latin praeter: beyond, and natura: nature

word.name: priapic
word.meaning: relating to male sexual activity
word.example: e.g. On their marriage night, War and Peace author Leo Tolstoy forced his wife to read extracts from his diaries detailing his prior priapic experiences.
word.etymology: priapic derives from the name of Priapos, who was the Greek god of male genitalia and fertility. The Greek myth surrounding Priapos is a particularly salacious one and goes as follows. His mother, Aphrodite, when pregnant with Priapos, won a beauty competition. The goddess who lost out to Aphrodite was so annoyed that she proceeded to curse Aphrodite's son, Priapos - who was still in the womb - to be born with a foul mind. As a result, when Priapos emerged into the world, he had an erection that would never subside. Today, we continue to refer to oversexed males as being priapic.

word.name: primordial
word.meaning: (of a quality) so fundamental as to have existed from the start of time
word.example: e.g. Any good ruler understands that his subjects require food and lodging, for these are mankind's primordial needs.
word.etymology: from the Latin primordialis: first of all, from primus: first, and ordiri: to begin

word.name: Procrustean
word.meaning: enforcing uniformity and stamping out individual quirks
word.example: e.g. Some people do believe in God but do not belong to a particular religion because they find the associated rules and regulations Procrustean.
word.etymology: Procrustean derives from the name of Procrustes, a torturer in Greek mythology. Procrustes would force his victims back to his house to try out his bed for size. If they were too long for the bed, he would chop their legs off; if they were too short, he would stretch their limbs. in the event that someone was the perfect fit for his bed, Procrustes had a differently-proportioned bed that he kept in reserve and would produce the one that was the worst fit for his victim, thus, guaranteeing some form of torture would ensue. Today, we call someone Procrustean if they try to fit people into excessively narrow limits with no regard for individuality.

word.name: profligate
word.meaning: ruinously extravagant
word.example: e.g. F. Scott Fitzgerald, author of The Great Gatsby, was so profligate that he would light his cigarettes with flaming five-dollar bills.
word.etymology: from the Latin profligare: to ruin

word.name: proliferate
word.meaning: to increase quickly in number
word.example: e.g. Pete Sampras won the US Open at the age of 19; from this point onwards, his list of Grand Slam wins proliferated rapidly.
word.etymology: from the Latin proles: offspring, and ferre: to carry

word.name: prolix
word.meaning: (of speech or writing) using too many words
word.example: e.g. Legal contracts are often prolix and so send most people to sleep.
word.etymology: from the Latin prolixus: poured forth, from pro: outward, and liquere: to be liquid

word.name: promulgate
word.meaning: (of an idea) to make known far and wide
word.example: e.g. The disciples found Jesus's sermons so compelling that they set out to promulgate his teaching.
word.etymology: from the Latin promulgare, from pro: out, and mulgare: to cause to come forth; promulgate literally means 'to milk'

word.name: propagate
word.meaning: to cause to spread
word.example: e.g. Actor Richard Gere propagates AIDS awareness around the world.
word.etymology: from the Latin propagare: to multiply from layers or shoots, from propago: a young shoot; propagate literally means 'to reproduce by natural processes from the parent stock'.

word.name: propitious
word.meaning: indicating a fair chance of success
word.example: e.g. Bjorn Borg would sport a beard when playing at Wimbledon because he believed that not shaving was propitious.
word.etymology: from the Latin propitius: favourable

word.name: proselytise
word.meaning: to convert (someone) from one belief to another
word.example: e.g. Christian missionary work has as its main goal that of proselytising non-believers.
word.etymology: from the Greek proselutos: a stranger or convert

word.name: protean
word.meaning: able to transform easily
word.example: e.g. The pop singer Madonna is a protean performer who undergoes frequent image transformations.
word.etymology: protean originates from the name of Proteus, a sea god in Greek mythology who could prophesy the future. People came from far and wide to ask Proteus about their fates. However, they were frequently disappointed, for Proteu's quirk was that he disliked being asked direct questions so much that he would change shape in order to confuse these inquisitors. Today, we still describe someone as protean if they have the ability to change rapidly.

word.name: prurient
word.meaning: having an unhealthy interest in sexual matters: or encouraging sexual matters
word.example: e.g. Errol Flynn had an active love life and he called his autobiography My Wicked, Wicked Ways, knowing this title would appeal to his prurient fan base.
word.etymology: from the Latin prurire: to itch, long

word.name: puckish
word.meaning: playful in a mischievous manner
word.example: e.g. Ian Fleming, the creator of James Bond, also wrote Chitty Chitty Bang Bang and other books for children to indulge in his puckish side.
word.etymology: deriving from the Middle English puke: an evil spirit

word.name: pullulate
word.meaning: to breed quickly; OR to be pulsing with life
word.example: e.g. Immediately before a big match, ticket touts pullulate around football stadiums.
word.etymology: from the Latin pullulare: to sprout, from the diminutive of pullus: young animal; pullulate literally means 'to breed so quickly as to become common'.

word.name: punctilious
word.meaning: showing huge attention to detail
word.example: e.g. Kingsley Amis would often write 500 words in punctilious fashion before drinking at lunchtime.
word.etymology: from the French pointaille: detail

word.name: (purdah) go into purdah
word.meaning: to go into social seclusion
word.example: e.g. After allegations of his infidelity surfaced, Tiger Woods went into self-imposed purdah.
word.etymology: purdah originates from the Persian word parda, which means 'a curtain', reflecting the Hindu or Muslim practice of 'purdah', which involved hiding women from the view of men. 'Purdah' is achieved either by the separation of the sexes or by women covering themselves with a 'burqa', which is a long, loose garment that covers the body from head to toe. Today, we use the phrase go into purdah to describe any instance of social seclusion, an activity most often practised by privacy-seeking celebrities.

word.name: purgative
word.meaning: ridding someone of unpleasant feelings
word.example: e.g. People who have received a shock often find alcohol a purgative.
word.etymology: from the Latin: to purify; purgative literally means 'having the effect of a strong laxiative'

word.name: purple prose
word.meaning: prose that is excessively ornate
word.example: e.g. Barbara Cartland might have shifted 500m copies of her romantic novels, but critics didn't like her writing, describing it as purple prose.
word.etymology: purple prose was term used by the Romans to describe fancy writing. The phrase came about because, in Roman times, purple dye was very expensive to manufacture because it necessitated the crushing of tens of thousands of molluscs (types of shellfish). Consequently, it was only the Emperor and the very wealthy who could afford purple garments. However, certain social climbers developed the habit of sewing small bits of purple onto their robes to give themselves a 'touch of class'. This activity was considered pretentious. In 65 BC, the poet Horace harnessed the negative connotations of the colour purple when he described pretentious writing as purple and this phrase is still used today.

word.name: purview
word.meaning: the extent of the influence (of someone or of something)
word.example: e.g. Many decisions carried out by the government are determined by ministers and do not come within the purview of the Prime Minister at all.
word.etymology: from the Old French purveu: forseen

word.name: pusillanimous
word.meaning: timid
