word.example: e.g. The character of James Bond is that of the alpha male: when you are hunting down terrorists, no pusillanimous streak can be indulged.
word.etymology: from the Latin pusillanimous, from pusillus: very small, and animus: mind

word.name: putrefy
word.meaning: to rot, emitting an unpleasant smell
word.example: e.g. If you discard prawns in a dustbin, there is soon an overpowering smell of putrefying crusacea.
word.etymology: from the Latin puter: rotten

word.name: quango
word.meaning: an agency that receives finance from a government while acting independently of it
word.example: e.g. The Press Complaints Commission (PCC) - to which the government has given the power to regulate all British newspapers - is a classic example.
word.etymology: quango is based originally on the 1970s' US acronym of 'qua(si) n(on) g(overnmental) o(rganisation).

word.name: quarry
word.meaning: the object of pursuit
word.example: e.g. After meeting Victoria Adams at a charity football match, David Bechham made her his quarry and eventually married her.
word.etymology: from the Old French curee: quarry, a hunting term that referred to the refuse parts of a slain animal that were given to the hounds in its skin (curee being based on the French cuir, meaning 'skin').

word.name: quiddity
word.meaning: the 'whatness' or intrinsic nature of someone or something
word.example: e.g. Certain novelists are so skilful that the reader feels he understands the singular quiddity of the lead character of the book better than that of his real-life spouse.
word.etymology: from the medieval Latin quidditas: whatness, from quid: what

word.name: quiescent
word.meaning: lying still
word.example: e.g. Maltreated workers may stay quiescent for years but will eventually mount a strike.
word.etymology: from the Latin quisecere: to be still

word.name: quixotic
word.meaning: very idealistic and unrealistic
word.example: e.g. It takes a quixotic individual - like actor Clark Gable - to believe in the institution of marriage sufficiently to attempt it six times.
word.etymology: quixotic derives from the name of Don Quixote, the hero of the famous 17th-century Spanish novel of the same name by the author Miguel de Cervantes. Don Quixote is a retired country gentleman who develops an obsession with tales of chivalry. Eventually he becomes delusional and, designating a neighbour as his squire and a farm girl as his ladylove, he embarks on a series of adventures. At the height of hos madness he attacks some windmills, believing them to be giants (Incidentally, this episode is the genesis of our modern-day expression 'tilting at windmmills', which means 'fighting an imaginary opponent'). Eventually he undergoes a return to sanity but is left feeling melancholic and dies a broken man. When we call someone quixotic, we mean they are like Don Quixote: full of grand chivalrous schemes but not living in the real world.

word.name: rabid
word.meaning: raving
word.example: e.g. Militant atheists depict fundamental Christians as being rabid.
word.etymology: rabid derives from the Latin rabere, which means 'to rave', and literally describes an animal made raving mad by rabies. We use the word figuratively to refer to a human who is 'foaming at the mouth' as they insist that their beliefs are correct; hence rabid is often used to describe religious extremists.

word.name: raillery
word.meaning: teasing of a light-hearted nature
word.example: e.g. People who are in a grumpy mood can respond badly to raillery.
word.etymology: from the French raillery: to rail

word.name: rapacious
word.meaning: snatching
word.example: e.g. Every year Arnold Schwarzenegger donates to charity his $175,000 salary as governor of California: he seems the opposite of a rapacious Hollywood star.
word.etymology: from the Latin rapacis: snatching.

word.name: realpolitik
word.meaning: a system of politics based on a practical - rather than a moral - approach
word.example: Before he became Prime Minister, the press often accused David Cameron of tailoring his views to suit public opinion and of other instances of realpolitik.
word.etymology: realpolitik refers to the implementation of a form of politics that is pragmatic - often at the expense of moral considerations. The first practitioner of realpolitik was Otto von Bismarck, Chancellor to Wilhelm I of the Kingdom of Prussia (a landmass covering parts of Germany and Russia); for example, keen to ensure the election of a Pope favourable to his own political aims, von Bismarck had no qualms about attempting to manipulate the Papal elections during the 1870s. Modern proponents include Richard Nixon who, for example, tolerated the human rights' violations of China as this meant greater global stability. Today, when we describe someone as practising realpolitik, we mean they are pragmatic - rather than principled - individuals; in other words, they are Machiavellian.

word.name: rebarbative
word.meaning: unpleasant-looking and aggressive
word.example: e.g. When Marlon Brando became depressed in old age, his weight ballooned and his appearance became rebarbative.
word.etymology: from the Old French se rebarber: to face each other 'beard to beard' in an aggressive fashion.

word.name: recalcitrant
word.meaning: refusing to cooperate with authority
word.example: e.g. Most men end up married despite initially feeling recalcitrant towards the institution.
word.etymology: from the Latin recalcitrare: to kick out with the heels, based on calx: a heel

word.name: recidivistic
word.meaning: (of a convicted criminal) tending to relapse into crime
word.example: e.g. Although the outlaw Jesse James carried out numerous successful heists, he was never satisfied with his takings, which led him to his recidivistic behaviour.
word.etymology: from the Latin recidivus: falling back, from the verb recidere, from re: back, and cadere: to fall

word.name: recondite
word.meaning: not well known
word.example: e.g. Schott's Original Miscellany is full of information of a recondite nature
word.etymology: from the Latin reconditus: hidden

word.name: recusant
word.meaning: defying an authority
word.example: e.g. Many teenagers object to eating meals at the dining table and are generally recusant.
word.etymology: from the Latin recusans: refusing

word.name: redound to
word.meaning: to contribute (to a person's reputation)
word.example: e.g. Salvador Dali would shave his armpits until they bled in the hope he'd appeal more to females; this act of masochism redounds to his reputation as a man who adored women.
word.etymology: from the Latin redundare: to overflow, from re: again, and unda: a wave

word.name: refulgent
word.meaning: shining
word.example: e.g. As Lorn Sugar's chauffeur pulled up outside the building, the car's metalwork was refulgent in the sunlight.
word.etymology: from the Latin refulgere: to shine out, from re: (an intensifying prefix) and fulgere: to shine

word.name: reliquary
word.meaning: a container for relics
word.example: e.g. Before admitting they would never fit her again, the fat woman tried some outfits from her reliquary of 'thin' clothes.
word.etymology: from the Old French relique: relic

word.name: rescind
word.meaning: to revoke (an arrangement)
word.example: e.g. Obama has rescinded some laws created by Bush
word.etymology: from the Latin re: (an intensifying prefix), and scindere: to divide

word.name: residuum
word.meaning: a thing that is left behind after a process
word.example: e.g. Grace Kelly is dead but her residuum of films continues to exist.
word.etymology: from the Latin residuus: remaining

word.name: retrousse
word.meaning: (of the nose) turned up
word.example: e.g. Rumours abounded that Michael Jackson had plastic surgery because the passing of the years saw his nose become increasingly retrousse
word.etymology: from the French re: back, and trousser: to turn

word.name: rhapsodise about
word.meaning: to talk about a topic with great passion
word.example: e.g. It is obvious from interviews that Prince Charles is in love with his wife Camilla because he often rhapsodises about her.
word.etymology: from the Greek rhapsodos: a bard who recites poetry (literally meaning 'someone who stitches songs together'), from rhaptein: to stitch, and oide: song

word.name: ribald
word.meaning: referring to sex in a funny but rude way
word.example: e.g. Frank Sinatra was popular with the ladies and, after a few drinks, would boast about his sexual exploits in a ribald way.
word.etymology: from the Old French riber: to indulge in licentious pleasures

word.name: rictus
word.meaning: a gaping grin
word.example: e.g. In photos Bill Clinton always seems to have a cheery demeanour, which is largely due to his permanent rictus
word.etymology: from the Latin rictus: a gaping of the jaws of an animal, from the past participle of the verb ringi: to gape

word.name: riparian
word.meaning: situated on a riverbank
word.example: e.g. Many paintings from the impressionist era feature couples picnicking against a riparian backdrop.
word.etymology: from the Latin ripa: bank

word.name: rococo
word.meaning: ornate in a tasteless way
word.example: e.g. The press likes to depict the large houses of Premier League footballers as tasteless blends of rococo features.
word.etymology: rococo describes many different forms of art, including music, architecture and woodwork. The rococo movement reached its peak in 18th-century Continental Europe and was characterised in furniture design by ornate spiral lines - hence the word's etymology from the French la rocaille, which means 'a garden made of rocks' (another example of an elaborate man-made creation). Examples of rococo art include the Palace of Versailles and the music of Vivaldi. Today, we continue to describe any intricate artwork as rococo.

word.name: roue
word.meaning: a sex-obsessed old man
word.example: e.g. After his trial for relations with a minor, Error Fylnn attached this notice to his door: 'Ladies: be prepared to produce your birth certificate'. What a roue!
word.etymology: The word roue has an interesting story behind it: in 18th century France, men who consorted with much younger women were punished by having their backs broken over a wheel (une roue). Today, we continue to describe dirty old men as roues.

word.name: rumbustious
word.meaning: out of control
word.example: e.g. Frank Sinatra was a hell-raiser who was famed for his rumbustious comportment.
word.etymology: from the Icelandic, ram: (an intensifying prefix), and bunctious: bumptious (which means 'self-assertive to an irritating degree')

word.name: Ruritanian
word.meaning: an inhabitant of Ruritania, a fictional country used by politicians and lawyers to illustrate a hypothetical case - especially if a reall country would object to be used in the example being considered
word.example: e.g. If France and Germany sign a security pact, this means these two countries will defend each other in case of attack by, say, the Ruritarians.
word.etymology: Ruritania was the name given by novelist Anthony Pope to a fictitious European country in his novel The Prisoner of Zenda (1894). Within literature, the word Ruritania has since been used to conjure up a fictitious country in Europe abounding with fairly-tale notions of chivalry and romance (as per Pope's novel). For example, Evelyn Waugh describes one character in his novel Vile Bodies as a sad 'ex-King of Ruritania'. Today, the fictional country of Ruritania is most often used in a more practical context: namely by politicians and lawyers to illustrate a hypothetical case - especially if a real country would object to being used in the example being considered.

word.name: salient
word.meaning: prominent
word.example: e.g. Thomas Jefferson was responsible for the invention of the coat hanger but he is remembered for being the US President because this is the salient fact of his life.
word.etymology: from the Latin salient: leaping (from the verb salire); salient literally means 'pointing outward'.

word.name: sangfroid
word.meaning: composure under pressure
word.example: e.g. Rugby star Jonny Wilkinson's sangfroid explains his ability to penalty kick under pressure.
word.etymology: from the French sang-froid: cold blood

word.name: sanguinary
word.meaning: involving the spilling of much blood
word.example: e.g. Vlad the Impaler (1431-1476) would murder his victims in particularly sanguinary ways as he liked to drink their blood after killing them.
word.etymology: from the Latin sanguis, sanguinis: blood

word.name: sanguine
word.meaning: optimistic
word.example: e.g. After divorcing his fifth wife, actor Clark Gable was sanguine about his chances of finding love again: sure enough, he soon found wife number six.
word.etymology: from the Latin sanguis, sanguinis: blood; sanguine literally means 'bloody in colour'

word.name: sardonic
word.meaning: dourly cynical
word.example: e.g. Comedian Lewis Grizzard once sardonically commented: 'Instead of getting married again, I'm going to find a woman I don't like and just give her the house'.
word.etymology: sardonic derives from the ancient Greeks' belief that eating a certain plant from the country of Sardo (which was the Greek's name for Sardinia) would cause facial contortions that resembled those of sardonic laughter; death usually followed. Today, we continue to use sardonic to mean 'grimly cynical'; and 'gallows humour' (i.e. humour arising from life-threatening situations) is one manifestation of a sardonic sense of humour.

word.name: saturnine
word.meaning: (of a person) slow and dark (in colouring) and melancholic
word.example: e.g. Henry VIII's weight gain in old age made him slow and depressed: he had become saturnine.
word.etymology: Saturnine derives from the medieval Latin Saturninus, which means 'of Saturn'. In medieval times, Saturn was considered by astrologers to be the coldest and darkest of the planets because it was thought to be the furthest from the sun. When we describe someone as saturnine today, we summon up these negative qualities.

word.name: scabrous
word.meaning: indecent
word.example: e.g. The media are fond of quoting John F. Kennedy's scabrous comment: 'If I don't have a woman for three days, I get terrible headaches'
word.etymology: from the Latin scaber: rough; scabrous literally means 'covered with scabs'

word.name: scatological
word.meaning: concerning excrement
word.example: e.g. Although some adults find fart jokes amusing, most people outgrow their scatological sense of humour of their youth.
word.etymology: from the Greek skor, skatos: excrement, and logos: word

word.name: schadenfreude
word.meaning: the pleasure experienced when someone other that you has a mishap
word.example: e.g. When Emperor Nero's wife pointed out he was late for dinner, he kicked her to death; on hearing this news, not even her fiercest enemies felt schadenfreude
word.etymology: from the German Schaden: harm, and freude: joy

word.name: scintilla
word.meaning: no more than a spark of a feeling
word.example: e.g. He may have started as the underdog in the Tory leadership race in 2005, but David Cameron's faith in his speech-making ability gave him a scintilla of hope.
word.etymology: from the Latin scintilla: spark

word.name: sclerotic
word.meaning: rigid, unable to adapt
word.example: e.g. The marriage between Marie Antoinette and Louis XVI wasn't consummated until its seventh year: theirs was a sclerotic relationship.
word.etymology: from the Greek skleros: hard, sclerotic literally means 'becoming rigid'

word.name: scrofulous
word.meaning: relating to a form of tuberculosis that produces glandular swellings; OR morally degenerate
word.example: e.g. The squalid environment of some jails abroad can make the inmates scrofulous.
word.etymology: from the Latin scrofulae: a swelling of the glands (diminutive of scrofa: a sow, which was said to be subject to the disease)

word.name: sedition
word.meaning: conduct inciting people to overthrow an authority
word.example: e.g. Hitler used force to quell sedition
word.etymology: from the Latin seditio, from sed: apart, and itio: going (from the verb ire: to go)

word.name: sedulous
word.meaning: showing diligence
word.example: e.g. Mother Theresa worked sedulously to alleviate the suffering of the poor.
word.etymology: from the Latin sedulus: zealous

word.name: segue
word.meaning: to make a smooth transition from one thing to another
word.example: e.g. After retiring from acting, Paul Newman sequed successfully into the business world, creating a profitable empire from making cooking sauces.
word.etymology: from the Italian seque: follows

word.name: seismic
word.meaning: of earth-shattering proportions
word.example: e.g. The events of September the 11th, 2001 had a seismic impact on world peace for years to come.
word.etymology: from the Greek seismos: earthquake

word.name: seminal
word.meaning: strongly influencing future developments
word.example: e.g. After being rejected for a job at the Foreign Office, Ian Fleming decided to create his alter ego, James Bond: so this snub was the seminal moment in the spy's creation.
word.etymology: from the Latin seminalis, from semen: seed; seminal literally means 'relating to semen'

word.name: semiotics
word.meaning: the study of signs and symbols
word.example: e.g. In the novel The Da Vinci Code, a professor of semiotics at Harvard uses his knowledge to solve a series of puzzles and unearth a conspiracy.
word.etymology: from the Greek semeioun: to interpret as a sign

word.name: sententious
word.meaning: given to expressing pompous opinions
word.example: e.g. When they preach to their congregation, priests must avoid sounding sententious
word.etymology: from the Latin sententia: opinion

word.name: seraglio
word.meaning: the harem in a Muslim palace
word.example: e.g. It would be no surprise to learn that Saddam Hussein's palace contains a seraglio
word.etymology: from the Persian saray: palace

word.name: serendipitous
word.meaning: relating to the occurrence of events by chance and with a positive outcome
word.example: e.g. For his 12th birthday, Elvis Presley wanted a bike but his mother could only afford a guitar: this proved to be a serendipitous gift for someone as musically talented as 'The King'.
word.etymology: serendipitous derives from the title of The Three Princes of Serendip, the English version of a fairy tale published in Venice in 1557 and to which author Horace Walpole referred in a letter he wrote in 1754. In the story, the three princes had a habit of stumbling across good things, or, as Walpole put it: 'were always making discoveries, by accidents and sagacity, of things they were not in the quest of'. Today, we use the word serendipitous to describe any chance event with a similarly joyful outcome.

word.name: Shangri-La
word.meaning: an earthly paradise that is a retreat from the confusion of civilisation
word.example: e.g. Oprah Winfrey lives on a huge California estate called 'The Promised Land', which overlooks the ocean: this is her own Shangri-La
word.etymology: Shangri-La is a fictional place described in the 1933 novel Lost Horizon by James Hilton. In the novel, Shangri-La is a paradise in Tibet enclosed by mountains; its inhabitants have a peculiarly long lifespan and barely display signs of ageing. Shangri-La is now used to denote any joyful land that is isolated from the outside world; it can also be used to denote a lifelong quest - fro example, for a man who is obsessed with becoming prime minister, this goal is his Shangri-La.

word.name: shibboleth
word.meaning: a phrase or concept identified with a particular group
word.example: e.g. By using the shibboleth of a 'just war' to describe his invasion of Iraq, Tony Blair is attempting to frame his actions within a wider religious and historical context.
word.etymology: shibboleth originates from a particularly bloody account in the Old Testament. In the passage (Judges 12:6), the Gileadites are pursuing the fleeing Ephraimites, whom the Gileadites have just defeated in battle. To identify a man as an Ephraimite, the Gileadites would ask him to say the word shibboleth (which means 'an ear of corn' in Hebrew); the Ephraimites could not pronounce this word correctly because they lacked a 'sh' sound in their dialect. Ephraimites would therefore fail the pronunciation test and then be slaughtered. Today, shibboleth is used to describe any phrase particular to a narrow group of people (such as 'credit derivatives', a phrase only bankers would claim to understand) or an experience common to one group (such as circumcision in the Jewish faith).

word.name: sibilant
word.meaning: sounding like a hiss
word.example: e.g. The phrase 'she sells seashells on the seashore' is particularly sibilant.
word.etymology: from the Latin sibilare: to hiss

word.name: simian
word.meaning: like a monkey
word.example: e.g. When Charles Darwin published his book On the Origin of Species in 1859, newspapers responded by printing cartoons of Darwin in a simian guise.
word.etymology: from the Latin simia: an ape

word.name: simpatico
word.meaning: (of a person) likeable
word.example: e.g. Michael Parkinson was an effective chat show host because he put guests at ease with his simpatico manner.
word.etymology: from the Italian simpatico: sympathetic

word.name: simper
word.meaning: to smile in a flirty fashion
word.example: e.g. Julia Roberts became an international sex symbol due to her role in the film Pretty Woman (1990) in which she simpered continually at the camera.
word.etymology: from the German zimpfer: delicate

word.name: simulacrum
word.meaning: a representation of someone or something (usually a poor representation)
word.example: e.g. The 2008 film of Brideshead Revisited was panned by critics as an inferior simulacrum of the book.
word.etymology: from the Latin simulacrum: a representation

word.name: slough off
word.meaning: to peel off (an old skin)
word.example: e.g. As a result of his army service in Afghanistan, Prince Harry succeeded in sloughing off his 'playboy' image.
word.etymology: deriving from the Low German slu(we): peel

word.name: smorgasbord
word.meaning: a wide range of something
word.example: e.g. Baptism and confession are regarded by atheists as parts of a smorgasbord of religious superstitions.
word.etymology: from the Swedish smorgas: slice of bread and butter, and bord: table; a smorgasbord literally refers to a buffet offering a variety of foods.

word.name: sobriquet
word.meaning: a nickname
word.example: e.g. Owing to his command of language, novelist Henry James received the sobriquet 'the Master'.
word.etymology: from the Old French sobriquet: a tap under the chin, from sous: under, and briquet: throat

word.name: sodality
word.meaning: a fraternity of people
word.example: e.g. The villains in Dan Brown's novel The Da Vinci Code are members of Opus Dei, a real-life Roman Catholic sodality.
word.etymology: from the Latin sodalis: comrade

word.name: soigne
word.meaning: maintaining a polished experience
word.example: e.g. In his heyday, actor Roger Moore was renowned for his soigne good looks.
word.etymology: from the French soigne: taken care of

word.name: solecism
word.meaning: (in speech) a grammatical error
word.example: e.g. Some people think it is a solecism to split the infinitive, such as in the phrase 'to work really hard'.
word.etymology: from the Greek soloikos: speaking incorrectly

word.name: solipsistic
word.meaning: obsessed with one's own feelings
word.example: e.g. Truman Capote so admired an article about himself that he wallpapered his flat with 500 copies of the magazine in question: how solipsistic of him.
word.etymology: from the Latin solus: along, and ipse: self

word.name: sop
word.meaning: something given to pacify (such as a bribe)
word.example: e.g. Bankers, at government-supported banks, complain that plans to cut their bonuses are a sop to angry taxpayers, say critics.
word.etymology: A sop meant 'bread dipped in liquid' in Middle English. The current sense of sop as being something designed to pacify someone came from the epic poem The Aeneid, written by Virgil (70-19BC). At one point in the Aeneid, the hero Aeneas decides to enter the underworld to see his dead father. Aeneas consults the guardian to the underworld, a prophetess called 'the Sibyl'. Knowing that the underworld is patrolled by a monstrous dog 'the Sibyl' prepares a sop soaked in honey and drugs to stupefy this animal; the plan works and the sop renders the dog comatose. Hence, today, a sop continues to mean 'something given to pacify' and often describes a small thing done as a concession to appease someone whose main demands are not being met.

word.name: sophistry
word.meaning: the use of unsound arguments, especially with the intention of outwitting someone
word.example: e.g. When clients asked fraudster Bernard Madoff about his investment strategies, Madoff would use complicated language and sophistry to confuse them.
word.etymology: from the Greek sophistes: a sophist (a person who reasons with witty but unsound arguments)

word.name: sororal
word.meaning: of or like a sister
word.example: e.g. Tennis stars Venus and Serena Williams enjoy a healthy sororal rivalry.
word.etymology: from the Latin soror: sister

word.name: specious
word.meaning: seeming plausible, but actually incorrect
word.example: e.g. When Daniel Craig appeared as the new James Bond in Casino Royale, reports that Pierce Brosnan would continue in the role were proved specious
word.etymology: from the Latin speciosus: fair

word.name: splenetic
word.meaning: bad-tempered
word.example: e.g. Inspector Morse's perpetual whisky-induced hangover perhaps explained why he was so splenetic.
word.etymology: splenetic derives from the Latin word splen, which means 'spleen'. This is because the ancient Greeks believed that the spleen - which is an organ involved in the creation and removal of blood cells - produced black bile which could darken someone's mood. Today, we continue to describe someone as splenetic if that person is in a strop.

word.name: spoonerism
word.meaning: an error in speech when the initial sounds of two or more words are transposed, often to comic effect
word.example: e.g. The teacher meant to say 'you have missed the history lectures' but it came out as 'you have hissed the mystery lectures'; the class erupted in laughter at this spoonerism.
word.etymology: spoonerism is a term that takes its name from an English clergyman and scholar called William Archibald Spooner (1844 and 1930). Reverend Spooner was notorious for confusing the letters at the start of adjacent words. For example, he is alleged to have said in church: 'The lord is my shoving leopard'. Today, we use the word spoonerism to describe any instance of someone confusing the letters at the start of adjacent words.

word.name: stentorian
word.meaning: (of a person's voice) loud and strong
word.example: e.g. Arnold Schwarzenegger was chosen to star in action films because of his muscular physique and stentorian voice.
word.etymology: stentorian derives from the name of a man called Stentor, who in Greek mythology was the herald for the Greek forces during the Trojan War. In his work The Odyssey, Greek poet Homer notes that the loudness of Stentor's voice was equal to that of fifty men combined; however, Stentor's voice was not louder that a god's and he shouted himself to death during an unsuccessful attempt to defeat the god Hermes in a shouting contest. Today, the adjective stentorian is used to describe someone with a booming voice.

word.name: stucco
word.meaning: fine plaster used for coating walls or moulding into decorative features
word.example: e.g. Hello magazine often features photos of footballers' houses that have been made ornate by the use of stucco.
word.etymology: from the Old German stukki: a fragment

word.name: Sturm und Drang
word.meaning: unpleasant emotional turbulence
word.example: e.g. During their teenage years most people are prone to Sturm und Drang.
word.etymology: Sturm und Drang is a German expression meaning 'Storm and Stress'. The Sturm und Drang movement originated in Germany at the end of the 18th century and involves the venting of spleen and anguish; this was as a reaction against the rigidity of the rationalism imposed by the Enlightenment movement. The most famous piece of literature of the time was Goethe's Die Leiden des jungen Werthers (The Suffering of Young Werther), a novel which describes a man so lovelorn that he kills himself. Today, when we describe someone as suffering from Sturm und Drang, we mean they are in a state of unpleasant emotional turmoil.

word.name: suborn
word.meaning: to bribe or otherwise persuade (someone) to commit a crime
word.example: e.g. To achieve their ends, politicians in Africa are often accused of suborning public institutions such as the media.
word.etymology: from the Latin subornare: to incite secretly, from sub: secretly, and ornare: to equip

word.name: sulphurous
word.meaning: erupting with anger
word.example: e.g. In his heyday, John McEnroe's sulphurous comments to referees made for great newspaper stories.
word.etymology: sulphurous literally means 'containing sulphur'; sulphur is a chemical with which gunpowder and other explosives are formed. So, when we describe someone as sulphurous, it means that person is about to explode with anger.

word.name: superannuated
word.meaning: too old to be of use
word.example: e.g. Though she is now in her 80s, the Queen continues to perform many duties with great efficiency: no one would say she is superannuated.
word.etymology: from the Latin super: over, and annus: year

word.name: supercilious
word.meaning: behaving as though one thinks one is above other people
word.example: e.g. Supercilious people have a manner that causes offence to others.
word.etymology: from the Latin superciliosus: haughty, from supercilium: eyebrow

word.name: supplicant/suppliant
word.meaning: (of a person) making a humble plea to a leader
word.example: e.g. Spike Milligan once called Prince Charles a 'little grovelling bastard' on live TV as a joke; but it is clear from this that the comedian was no supplicant.
word.etymology: from the Latin supplicare: to implore

word.name: suppurate
word.meaning: to form pus
word.example: e.g. Some women who have breast augmentation operations experience suppurating wounds for days afterwards.
word.etymology: from the Latin sub: below, and pus, puris: pus

word.name: susurrate
word.meaning: to murmur softly
word.example: e.g. Top judge by his manly appearance, you would expect footballer David Beckham to have a loud voice; yet in interviews he usually susurrates.
word.etymology: from the Latin susurrare: to murmur

word.name: Svengali
word.meaning: a person who controls another
word.example: e.g. Simon Fuller has managed the Spice Girls and other celebrities, which resulted in the press giving him the title of 'management Svengali'.
word.etymology: Svengali originates from the name of a character in the 1894 novel Trilby by George du Maurier. In the book, Svengali is a character who uses hypnosis to control the singing voice of a weaker character called Trilby. Today, when we call someone a Svengali, we mean they are similarly controlling of someone else - usually in a sinister way.

word.name: sybarite
word.meaning: a person who is overly fond of luxury
word.example: e.g. Charlie Chaplin used to frequent a brothel called The House of All Nations, which was a popular haunt of wealthy sybarites.
word.etymology: sybarite literally means 'an inhabitant of Sybarus'; Sybarus was a city in Italy that existed in the 6th century BC. Owing to the fertility of the surrounding soil, the inhabitants of Sybarus were among the wealthiest people in the world and were renowned for pampering themselves: the city was sufficiently well off to install the first street-lighting system in history. Today, a sybarite is someone who has a fondness for sensory indulgence.

word.name: sylph
word.meaning: a thin female
word.example: e.g. Despite being over 50 years old, Madonna retains the appearance of a sylph as a result of her exercise regime.
word.etymology: from the Modern Latin sylphes: a spirit inhabiting the air; a sylph literally means 'an imaginary spirit of the air'.

word.name: symposium
word.meaning: a meeting to discuss one topic in particular
word.example: e.g. Samuel Beckett, author of Waiting for Godot, could go for hours without saying a word: he was not someone to seek out at a symposium.
word.etymology: from the Latin symposiium from the Greek symposion: an occasion for drinking together, from sun: together, and potes: drinker

word.name: synaesthesia
word.meaning: the evocation of one sense by the stimulating of another sense
word.example: e.g. Whenever I smell smoke from my uncle's pipe, I immediately think of my dead aunt playing the piano; this synaesthesia leaves me giddy.
word.etymology: from the Greek sun: together, and oesthesis: sensation

word.name: synapse
word.meaning: a connection between two nerve cells; to displace the beats in music so that strong beats become weak and weak beats become loud
word.example: e.g. When a thought comes into our head, electricity travels across the synapses in our brain.
word.etymology: from the Greek sun: together, and hapsis: joining

word.name: syncopate
word.meaning: to shorten a word by dropping sounds in the word's middle
word.example: e.g. People who think they are amusing when they syncopate words (such as by pronouncing the south London suburb of 'Clapham' as 'Cl'hm') are in fact annoying.
word.etymology: from the Latin syncopare: to swoon

word.name: synecdoche
word.meaning: a figure of speech in which a part is used to allude to the whole, or the whole is used to allude to a part
word.example: e.g. A thief notorious for his ability to pick pockets is often called 'Fingers', this term being a synecdoche for his body as a whole.
word.etymology: from the Greek synekdokhe: a receiving together, from syn: with, ek: out, and dekhesthai: to receive (related to dokein: to seem good)

word.name: tabula rasa
word.meaning: the mind before it has been imprinted with the effects of experience
word.example: e.g. The brain of a baby is a tabula rasa on to which the baby's parents etch their values.
word.etymology: from the Latin tabula: tablet, and rasa: erased

word.name: tangential
word.meaning: digressing from a prior course
word.example: e.g. Cameron and Osborne arranged a dinner to discuss the economy but ended up discussing tangential matters.
word.etymology: from the Latin tangere: to touch; tangential literally means 'touching at a point without intersecting'.

word.name: Tartuffe
word.meaning: a hypocritical pretender to any kind of superiority
word.example: e.g. J. Edgar Hoover, the first director of the FBI, called Playboy readers 'moral degenerates'; but he was a Tartuffe because he regularly watched pornographic films.
word.etymology: Tartuffe is the lead character in the play Tartuffe, written by the French playwright Maliere n 1664. In the play, Tartuffe persuades the other characters that he is pious and devout, whilst he is actually lustful and grasping. This rank hypocrisy is eventually revealed to all in the closing scenes. Today, we call someone a Tartuffe if that person is a hypocrite of the highest order.

word.name: tautology
word.meaning: expressing the same concept twice using different words (considered to be at fault of style)
word.example: e.g. The phrase 'frozen ice' is a tautology: all ice is frozen so there is no need for the adjective 'frozen'
word.etymology: from the Greek tauto: same, and logos: word

word.name: tawdry
word.meaning: sordid and unpleasant
word.example: e.g. Many a glamour model has been paid a small fortune by the media to give a tawdry account of an affair with a married footballer.
word.etymology: tawdry is a contraction of the name of Saint Audrey, an Anglo-Saxon saint. In the 17th century, devotees of Saint Audrey staged an annual fair where lace clothes would be sold. However, Puritans consider lace to look seedy and so it was that Saint Audrey - and the word tawdry that is a contraction of her name - became associated with tackiness. Today, we use tawdry to describe something that is sordid and cheap.

word.name: teleological
word.meaning: relating to the explanation of living things by the purpose they serve rather than by their origins
word.example: e.g. Religious people believed that our lives are subject to a teleological framework.
word.etymology: from the Greek telos: end, and logos: word

word.name: tendentious
word.meaning: marked by a strong point of view, implicitly expressed
word.example: e.g. The BBC is required to produce programmes that have no political or other agenda, so there is no tendentious editing at the Beeb.
word.etymology: from the Medieval Latin tendentia: a cause, from the Latin tendere: to stretch.

word.name: tenebrous
word.meaning: shadowy
word.example: e.g. In his youth, Sean Connery worked as a coffin-polisher in a tenebrous building occupied by a funeral director.
word.etymology: from the Latin tenebrae: darkness

word.name: tenet
word.meaning: a principle
word.example: e.g. That Muhammed received a series of revelations from God is one of the main tenets of Islam.
word.etymology: from the Latin tenet, which means 'he holds', from the verb tenere: to hold

word.name: termagant
word.meaning: a scolding woman
word.example: e.g. Kathrine Hepburn would insist on sniffing the hair of her co-stars to make sure it was clean: such intrusive behaviour is typical of a termagant.
word.etymology: termagant was the name of a character in medieval morality plays. Termagant was a fictitious male Muslim deity with a violent nature who appeared in medieval morality plays. As Termagant wore long gowns, English audiences mistakenly believed the character was female. Today, when we call a woman a termagant, it means she has a scolding nature.

word.name: theocrat
word.meaning: a leader who rules in the name of God
word.example: e.g. Until Japan's defeat in World War II - when Emperor Hirohito was forced to deny that the Emperor of Japan was divine - Japan was rules by theocrats.
word.etymology: from the Greek theos: god, kratos: rule

word.name: tinnitus
word.meaning: a ringing sound in the ears (often caused by a specific condition such as a head injury)
word.example: e.g. After leaving a loud pop concert, people often have tinnitus in both ears.
word.etymology: from the Latin tinnire: to ring, tinkle

word.name: tithe
word.meaning: ten percent of someone's income that is contributed to the Church
word.example: e.g. Hundreds of years ago, most Christians paid the tithe; now very few do.
word.etymology: from the Middle English tithe, from the Anglo-Saxon tien: ten

word.name: topography
word.meaning: the way the physical features of an area are arranged
word.example: e.g. The SAS troops needed to become familiar with every nook and cranny of Pakistan so they spent months studying the country's topography.
word.etymology: from the Greek topographia, from topos: place, and graphe: writing

word.name: totalitarian
word.meaning: a person advocating a dictatorship that requires total submission to the state
word.example: e.g. World leaders hope the openness displayed by China at events such as the Olympics is a sign that the government is relaxing its totalitarian stance.
word.etymology: from the Latin totus: whole, entire

word.name: totemic (of)
word.meaning: markedly symbolic (of)
word.example: e.g. For most people the Queen is the totemic member of the Royal Family.
word.etymology: totemic finds its root in the French word aoutem, which means an object considered by Indians to be the emblem of a clan. Totems were usually an animal or an object from nature; as well as being representative of a clan, totems were believed to protect the clansmen. Today, when we describe a person or thing being as totemic, we mean that it is distinctly symbolic of something.

word.name: touchstone
word.meaning: a benchmark by which something is judged
word.example: e.g. Roger Federer holds more Grand Slam titles than any other player in the history of tennis; his achievement is the touchstone for all future players.
word.etymology: A touchstone refers to a piece of dark jasper which was used to test the purity of a gold alloy by observing the colour of the mark the alloys made on it. The streak left behind was compared to the clear yellow streak left by pure gold. Today, we call something a touchstone when it provides a standard by which to judge other things. (see also paragon, which has a near0identical meaning).

word.name: transmogrify
word.meaning: to transform, especially in a way that is not expected
word.example: e.g. When he invented Facebook, Marc Zuckerberg was transmogrified fro mHarvard postgraduate to the youngest self-made billionaire on the planet.
word.etymology: deriving from the verb transmigrate: (of the soul) to pass into another body after death/

word.name: trenchant
word.meaning: (of language or a person) incisive and cutting
word.example: e.g. When people talk about failed romantic relationships, their tone of voice often becomes trenchant.
word.etymology: from the Old French trenchant: cutting, from the verb trenchier, itself based on the LAtin, truncare: to maim

word.name: triumvirate/troika
word.meaning: a group of three people working alongside each other
word.example: e.g. A triumvirate/troika of film moguls - Spielberg, Geffen and Katzenberg - set up the studio Dreamworks.
word.etymology: triumvirate derives from the Latin trium virum, the genetive plural of tres viri: three men; troika derives from the Russian troe: set of three. The so-called First Triumvirate was an informal political alliance of Julius Caesar, Pompeius Magnus ("Pompey the Great") and Marcus Crassus. The arrangement had no legal status, and its purpose was to consolidate the political power of the three and their supporters against the senatorial elite. After the death of Crassus in 53 BC, the two survivors fought a civil war, during which Pompey was killed and Caesar established his sole rule as perpetual dictator. The Second Triumvirate was recognized as a triumvirate at the time. A Lex Titia formalized the rule of Octavian, Mark Antony, and Marcus Aemilius Lepidus. The legal language makes reference to the traditional tresviri. This "three-man commission for restoring the constitution of the republic" (tresviri rei publicae constituendae) in fact was given the power to make or annul law without approval from either the Senate or the people; their judicial decisions were not subject to appeal, and they named magistrates at will. Although the constitutional machinery of the Republic was not irrevocably dismantled by the Lex Titia, in the event it never recovered. Lepidus was sidelined early in the triumvirate, and Antony was eliminated in civil war, leaving Octavian the sole leader.

word.name: trope
word.meaning: a common theme; OR the use of words in a non-literal way, such as a metaphor
word.example: e.g. Much of the tension in the horror film The Shining derives from the trope of the psychic child who has the ability to foresee imminent evil.
word.etymology: from the Greek tropos: turn, way

word.name: truculent
word.meaning: quick to fight
word.example: e.g. Actor Errol Flynn blew the money he had saved for an engagement ring at the bookies; his truculent fiancée broke up with him as a result.
word.etymology: from the Latin trux, trucis: fierce

word.name: turpitude
word.meaning: corruption
word.example: e.g. The US government still bars from entering the country those people considered to be in a state of moral turpitude.
word.etymology: from the Latin turpis: disgraceful

word.name: tussock
word.meaning: a small patch of grass that is longer than the grass surrounding it
word.example: e.g. If you have mowed your lawn properly no tussocks will remain.
word.etymology: tussock derives from a 16th-century alternation of 'tusk', which meant a 'tuft'

word.name: ululate
word.meaning: to utter howling sounds
word.example: e.g. During the funeral scenes in the Godfather films, old women in black ululate around the coffin.
word.etymology: from the Latin ululare: to howl, shriek

word.name: utilitarian
word.meaning: useful, rather than beautiful
word.example: e.g. Although most fridges are not beautiful, they are utilitarian.
word.etymology: from the Latin utilis: useful

word.name: utopia
word.meaning: an imagined place in which everything is in perfect harmony
word.example: e.g. Kristen Scott Thomas's father was a Royal Navy pilot; when he died in a flying accident, this shattered the utopia of her childhood.
word.etymology: utopia has a rather depressing etymology - for it derives from the Greek words ou (meaning 'not') and topos (meaning 'a place'): in other words, a utopia or a sense of happiness is a place that does not exist. The word utopia was popularised by Sir Thomas More (who was beheaded by Henry VIII). In Of the Best State of a Republic and of the New Island Utopia (1516), More depicts the island of Utopia as a landmass where harmony reigns thanks to its perfect social and political structure. Today, we continue to refer to any perfect place as being a utopia. (For the opposite of a utopia - i.e. a place where discord reigns - see dystopia)

word.name: uxorious
word.meaning: (of a husband) displaying an indulgent fondness for one's wife
word.example: e.g. On the TV show Richard and Judy, Richard's constant attention to his wife Judy gave the impression of an uxorious man.
word.etymology: from the Latin uxor: wife

word.name: vagabond
word.meaning: a person without a home who wanders around
word.example: e.g. After his widowed mother was certified insane, Charlie Chaplin left school to join a dance troupe and become, in effect, a vagabond.
word.etymology: from the Latin vagari: to wander

word.name: vagaries
word.meaning: unforeseen changes in a situation
word.example: e.g. Winston Churchill often felt the urge to throw himself off railway platforms because he was prone to the vagaries of manic depression.
word.etymology: from the Latin vagari: to wander

word.name: vainglorious
word.meaning: characterised by vanity and boasting
word.example: e.g. Some religious people regard atheists as being vainglorious for denying the existence of God.
word.etymology: from the Old French vaine gloire: vain glory

word.name: valedictory
word.meaning: serving as a farewell
word.example: e.g. In his final months in office, Tony Blair appeared on several TV chat shows in a kind of valedictory tour.
word.etymology: from the Latin vale: goodbye, and dicere: to say

word.name: vampish
word.meaning: relating to a woman who uses sexual attraction to manipulate men
word.example: e.g. The nature of the relationship between John F. Kennedy and Marilyn Monroe was clear from the vampish way in which she sang: 'Happy Birthday, Mr President'.
word.etymology: vampish derives from an early 20th-century abbreviation of 'vampire'

word.name: vapid
word.meaning: dull, unstimulating
word.example: e.g. The piped music played in aeroplanes awaiting take-off invariably is vapid.
word.etymology: from the Latin vapidus: flat

word.name: vaudeville
word.meaning: a stage play on a frivolous theme with songs along the way
word.example: e.g. Musicals such as Mary Poppins owe a lot to the tradition of vaudeville, a theatrical genre of variety entertainment popular in the US until the 1930s.
word.etymology: vaudeville derives from the French word vaudeville, which in the 15th century meant 'a popular song'. (The word vaudeville's formation in France can be traced to the most famous writer of such songs who lived in the valley of Vire, or, in French, the Vau de Vire). It was variety theatre owners in the US who adapted the expression vaudeville at the end of the 19th century in the hope that the Frenchness of the term might lend the halls an air of sophistication and thus differentiate them in the public's mind from the earlier variety halls which were marked by rowdiness. Today vaudeville refers to any entertainment made up of a series of short musical sketches and with a light-hearted theme.

word.name: (much) vaunted
word.meaning: much praised
word.example: When Charlie Chaplin came third in a Charlie Chaplin lookalike contest, he had to admit that the winner, a much vaunted lookalike, did bear an uncanny resemblance to him.
word.etymology: from the Old French vanter: to praise, based on the Latin vanitare: to talk frivolously (from the Latin vanare: to utter empty words, from vanus: empty)

word.name: venal
word.meaning: being open to bribery
word.example: e.g. One months before the invasion of Iraq, Saddam Hussein made an offer to stand down peacefully in return for $1bn; he remained venal to the last.
word.etymology: from the Latin venum: thing for sale

word.name: venial
word.meaning: (of a fault) trivial
word.example: e.g. Russian monarch Ivan the Terrible, who used to roast humans alive, regarded his other pastimes - such as throwing dogs off towers - as no more than venal sins.

word.name: verbiage
word.meaning: writing that uses an excessive amount of words
word.example: e.g. Walt Disney often spoke about the need for cleanliness; proving his words were no mere verbiage, he would wash his own hands up to 30 times an hour.
word.etymology: from the French verbe: word

word.name: verdant
word.meaning: (of countryside) green with grass or other organic matter
word.example: e.g. A team of gardeners ensure the lawns of Buckingham Palace remain verdant at all times.
word.etymology: from the Old French verdoyant: becoming green, based on the Latin, virdare: to grow green.

word.name: vernacular
word.meaning: the everyday language spoken by the people in one region
word.example: e.g. Anti-Muslim attitudes are commonplace; this is reflected by the fact that the word 'Islamophobia' has entered the English vernacular.
word.etymology: from the Latin vernaculus: native, from verna: home-born slave

word.name: vicarious
word.meaning: feelings experienced in one person's mind via someone else's descriptions or display of their own feelings
word.example: e.g. When Fred Astaire's dancing prevented him from watching his beloved soap operas, he would phone his housemaid to experience the plot twists vicariously.
word.etymology: vicarious originates from the word 'vicar': both words are derived from the Latin vicarius, meaning 'substitute'. In the Catholic Church, a vicar is the 'representative' of a bishop; similarly, when a fried tells us a story about his recent car crash, our friend becomes our 'representative' during the moments that the vehicle crumpled, and we experience the crash vicariously.

word.name: vicissitude
word.meaning: an unpleasant change in a situation
word.example: e.g. When his wife died in a plane crash, Clark Gable kept her bedroom exactly as it was the day she caught the plane because he was so upset at this vicissitude.
word.etymology: from the Latin vicissum: by turns.

word.name: vilify
word.meaning: to talk about (someone) in a denigrating manner
word.example: e.g. When Roger Clinton, half-brother of Bill, pleaded guilty to cocaine distribution, the press vilified him.
word.etymology: from the Latin vilis: of low value

word.name: visceral
word.meaning: perceived as if in the internal organs (the viscera)
word.example: e.g. To fall in love at first sight is to experience an immediate visceral response to someone.
word.etymology: from the Latin viscera: the internal organs

word.name: vista
word.meaning: a distant view especially one seen through an opening
word.example: e.g. Dying of cancer in Switzerland, Audrey Hepburn had her bed positioned so she could see the mountains outside her window; she loved this vista.
word.etymology: from the Italian visto: seen, past participle of vedere: to see (from the Latin videre: to see); a vista literally means: 'a pleasing view seen through a long, narrow opening'.

word.name: vitiate
word.meaning: to harm the quality of
word.example: e.g. Told he was too sane for a psychiatric hospital, Spike Milligan stabbed Peter Sellers; in this way he vitiated his record of sanity and was admitted.
word.etymology: from the Latin vitare: to impair

word.name: vituperate
word.meaning: to speak very disparagingly about someone
word.example: e.g. When the 54-year-old Charlie Chaplin married the 18-year-old Oona O'Neill, the press vituperated him.
word.etymology: from the Latin vituperare: to disparage

word.name: voluptuary
word.meaning: a person devoted to self-indulgence
word.example: e.g. As a voluptuary, Oscar Wilde loved sensual indulgence, especially an activity he called 'feasting with panthers', which meant going with rent-boys.
word.etymology: from the Latin voluptas: pleasure

word.name: vulpine
word.meaning: like a fox
word.example: e.g. Alsatians are the most vulpine of dogs.
word.etymology: from the Latin vulpes: a fox

word.name: wainscot
word.meaning: an area of wooden panelling running along the bottom of some walls
word.example: e.g. Rooms in Victorian houses often have wainscot on the lower part of the walls of rooms.
word.etymology: from the medieval Flemish waghenscote: superior quality oak wood.

word.name: wanderlust
word.meaning: a yearning to travel
word.example: e.g. Graham Greene wrote novels set on several continents, all of which he had travelled across to sate his wanderlust.
word.etymology: from the German wandern: to wander, and lust: lust

word.name: wanton
word.meaning: (especially of a woman) sexually indecent; OR (of an action) deliberate and out of the blue
word.example: e.g. When he was just 18, William Shakespeare married a woman who was already clearly pregnant, leading to gossip accusing her of wanton behaviour.
word.etymology: from the Middle English wan: wanting, lacking, and togen: to discipline: together these words imply a notion of 'badly disciplined/badly brought up'.

word.name: waspish
word.meaning: very irritable
word.example: e.g. When working as a librarian, the poet Philip Larkin would ask people in a waspish tone: 'Why on earth are you borrowing drivel like that?'
word.etymology: from the word wasp, an insect renowned for its irritability.

word.name: wend
word.meaning: to travel slowly towards a particular goal
word.example: e.g. When exploring a new city, tourists are in no rush, usually preferring to wend their way around.
word.etymology: from the German wended: to turn

word.name: wheedle
word.meaning: to convince someone using flattery
word.example: e.g. In 'honey-trap' operations, female police officers use their wiles to wheedle information out of male murder suspects.
word.etymology: from the German wedeln: 'to wag the tail like a fawning dog', hence 'to fawn, flatter'.

word.name: widow's peak
word.meaning: a V-shaped growth of hair in the centre of the forehead left behind as the hairline recedes
word.example: e.g. With age, men often develop a widow's peak.
word.etymology: widow's peak derives from the old wives' tale that a V-shaped hair pattern on a man's forehead means he will die soon, leaving his wife a widow.

word.name: winnow (down)
word.meaning: to reduce the number (in a collection of things) until only the best ones remain
word.example: e.g. Every year 128 tennis players compete in the men's singles at Wimbledon; by the day of the finals their number has been winnowed down to just two contestants.
word.etymology: from the Old English windwian: to ventilate, from wind: wind; the literal meaning of winnow is 'to blow a current of air through (grain) in order to remove the chaff'.
